content:
Posted: March 24, 2015
 An overview for those unfamiliar with the "Dungeon Master" genre Shipwrecked!  Your band of four mysterious prisoners just washed up on a mysterious island, run by a mysterious master.  Fight enemies both mysterious and non-mysterious, and find mysterious items from mysterious chests by solving mysterious puzzles.If you've never played a game similar to this in the past, you're going to feel a bit confused, and perhaps turned off at first.  Although the game is concidered first-person, think of it like this - you are a floating camera, right in front of four party members.  That's right, you control all four.  Even more jarring for many will be the grid-based movement and combat.  The levels certainly don't appear much like grids, mut you move from grid-space to grid-space without any leeway.  No diagonal moves - only forward, back, and 90-degree turns.  This is one of my only complaints - it's restricive,  seemingly an un-neccisary "old school" feature, and sometimes makes me a little dizzy if I start making too many turns.  Controls are mostly menu based, requiring you to click on the weapon of a party member to attack and actually have non-weapon items (like alchemy equipment or warhorns) if you want to use them.  The games has a very nice map system which creates a classic grid-paper like map (nothing is labled for you, if you want to make note of something the game gives you the tools to do so)You would expect, concidering the grid system, that combat would be turn based.  Nope.  You'd better get used to the system quickly, because strafing and dodging opponent attacks are often vital tactics for survival.  This game is quite challenging at times, and I often find that I feel under-leveled for the area I'm in, even when I'm actually not.Character progression is handeled quite well - you never feel completely satisfied with your characters, which is how it should be.  Skills only have 5 levels, but you only get one point per level, and there is something like 20 skills.  Character classes actually feel different from one another and many have very unique benefits / systems.  Alchemists actually grow more herbs once they're in their inventory.  Magic users are treated to a magic system that involves combining different elemental runes to create spells.The environments are absolutely beautiful - this is possibly the nicest looking game I own, in my opinion.  But I'm a sucker for AA, so opinions may vary.  Everything is essentially open world.  The best comparison would probably be metroid, if only because most areas are blocked off by locked doors, the keys to which can only be found elsewhere.  That elsewhere is probably blocked off by some puzzles.  The puzzles are a nice level of difficulty, vague enough to leave you scratching your head, untill you figure them out, at which point you facepalm.And did I mention - you can make and download custom dungeons, some of which are campaign lenth?  It's a wonderful feature that adds huge amounts of value if you want to keep playing after you've finished the original campaign.  -Important Note-In the Windows version, custom dungeons are held in Documents\Almost Human\Legend of Grimrock 2\Dungeons.  Dungeons downloaded from the Steam Workshop are immediately brought there, but there are others on the Nexus which are too large to be allowed on the Workshop.  Place those dungeons in the aforementioned file as well.  Took me forever to figure that out.

content:
Posted: April 13, 2015
												A magnificent game.Hardly ever did I feel as challenged by a video game, both mentally and physically. Having played and loved the first title of the franchise, I was positively thrilled to learn about the sequel.For those who know the first game:Even though LoG1 was a great game, I always felt that staying inside all the time did not fulfill all of Grimrock's potential. I was amazed to see that LoG2 changed this impressively. The developers took some great steps forward with the sequel. Here's what's new: handsome graphics great soundtrack diversified outdoor locations!!! improved character creation process mystifying story 3D (layers of different altitude in one map) tremendously improved AI behaviour additional monsters,  new items, innovative spells, challenging puzzles tons of wealth: buried treasure, locked chests, golden caches, etc, gigantic 34 levels to explore! non-linear exploration - finally you have to ask yourself "Where to next?"Only small downside I experienced: Backtracking in order to search for something left out or testing a theory to a puzzle was sometimes hindered by hoardes of monsters guarding ares, which were already cleared out. This makes grinding possible to an extent, but was occasionally also quite time-consuming. Also, in my opinion the main story itself provides limited "replayability" since it's just not nearly as satisfying anymore if you already know where all the secrets are. I hope that the level-editor will result in some great fan-made additional content!Difficulty LevelThe game provides plenty of possibilities for the player to choose their own challenge. Five races, eight classes and 16 skills are paired with the need to form a specialized party of up to four characters. Three different difficulty settings govern the speed and thrill of the very dynamic combat system. As an Old-School RPG veteran I chose to play at the highest difficulty and preferred to draw my own maps instead of enabling the game's automap feature. Additional options exist to raise the challenge even higher. I was very happy to experience a higher difficulty setting not only in terms of more incoming damage and less output, but rather mainly in an increase of the combat's pace. I also didn't get stuck in an unfair combat situation, although different situations did often require to adapt one's strategy, which I highly appreciate in a game.Some puzzles were really challenging, having me ask my partner and roommates for advice and inspiration. I'm proud that I never used help from a guide or an internet discussion; with a reasonable amount of creativity it is possible to solve all of the riddles. Hardly any of the harder puzzles is story-relevant, so there's also the option of moving on and returning later to loot that particular room of booty.AtmosphereI mainly played in a candlelit room on a wall flat screen wearing headphones. I was often able to locate secret passages by the sounds of monsters behind walls. I could always tell from the direction of the sound in which corridor that blasted zombie was currently looking for me. On more than one occasion I heard myself scream in surprise or even fear when suddenly I realized some monster sneaked up on me! I highly recommend playing this game with an adept surround sound system! ConclusionIf you love hack'n'slay games, online raiding parties, bragging about your new epic item in front of your friends and skipping story and text in favor of action, this game is NOT for you!If you are an arachnophobiac, musophobiac, herpetophobiac, necrophobiac, nyctophobiac, hylophobiac, eremophobiac, ophidiophobiac or potamophobiac, this game is DEFINITELY not for you!If you like games emphasizing social interaction, telling a detailed, pre-cut and pre-chewed story or featuring a lot of spoken dialogue, you might consider asking yourself if you can do without any of this. If not, don't play it, you'll just be disappointed.To anybody else: By all means, give it a try! Chances are even if-unlike me-you don't find your next favourite video game, you will be having a great time on the beautiful Isle of Nex!

content:
Posted: July 9, 2016
												The sequel to the hit First-Person Dungeon-Crawl RPG, The Legend of Grimrock II improves on the previous game in so many ways! The gameplay, the music, the graphics, the dungeon layouts! Everything! So, let’s go into one of my trademark reviews and see just how much was improved!Gameplay: If you’ve played the first Legend of Grimrock, then the gameplay is going to feel extremely familiar. It’s the same as in the first game, but with a few minor tweaks that make playing the game so much more enjoyable. Firstly, you’ll notice that instead of being in a dungeon throughout the entire game like you were in the first game, in LoG 2 you spend most of your time outside with only needing to go into the dungeons (you read that right, in this game, there’s not just one dungeon, but a whole bunch of them!) whenever you need to solve some puzzles. The monster AI has been improved and multiple heights in dungeons were added, which kind of takes power away from the whole attack, sidestep/back away from enemies that worked throughout much of the previous game, although still doable to some degree. There’s more weapons and armor and skills and spells to learn, and new classes were added, as was a new race, meaning you have even more customization than you did in the previous game with your party generation. I also like how there are pools of water in the game and you can dive in and explore as if you were still on land but just slower moving. As I said, Almost Human has improved the Grimrock experience in many ways!Graphics: While the graphics look the same, they’re still really friggin’ beautiful! You have the same graphics engine that was used in the original Legend of Grimrock, but with more enviroments, more monsters, more weapons and armor, and more other stuff but I haven’t exactly beaten the game yet so I can’t tell you about all of the new graphics in the game.Music: The only music that I really know for a fact was new was the Grimrock II Title Theme, in addition to the new ambient sounds for forests, but that’s all I know of that changed.Story: I saved the best for last this time! In Legend of Grimrock II, as with the first Legend of Grimrock, your party is a group of prisoners who are accused of some unknown crime and are being transported somewhere (where, I don’t know, I don’t think the game exactly tells you) but during your “trip”, a storm brews and casts the ship your on into the Island of Nex (the game’s setting) and you have to find out why the Island Master has summoned you here so that you can leave. The story is a much better one than the one found in Legend of Grimrock I and, without spoiling the story too much, there’s a twist ending in the game! Even the old-school Dungeon Crawler RPGs that I’ve played couldn’t pull that off! Mind you, I’ve only truly played and beaten the Eye of the Beholder Trilogy (if you can call it that) and they didn’t have any twist endings. Overall, this is a game that shows just what a game company, no matter how large or how small, can do, especially when they’re this dedicated to improving their games’ experiences and I should hope that, should Legend of Grimrock III ever come to light (and I’m really hoping it does), then may Almost Human improve upon this game’s strengths, and make an even better one. Really, this is the classic story of a game company that could’ve used the Legend of Grimrock I Dungeon Editor to make another dungeon similar to what was in the first game, but they didn’t, they took it a step further than that and completely re-tooled their old Dungeon Editor and make a similar, yet very different, Legend of Grimrock game. Hopefully, other game devs will follow in Almost Human’s footsteps.

												A magnificent game.Hardly ever did I feel as challenged by a video game, both mentally and physically. Having played and loved the first title of the franchise, I was positively thrilled to learn about the sequel.For those who know the first game:Even though LoG1 was a great game, I always felt that staying inside all the time did not fulfill all of Grimrock's potential. I was amazed to see that LoG2 changed this impressively. The developers took some great steps forward with the sequel. Here's what's new: handsome graphics great soundtrack diversified outdoor locations!!! improved character creation process mystifying story 3D (layers of different altitude in one map) tremendously improved AI behaviour additional monsters,  new items, innovative spells, challenging puzzles tons of wealth: buried treasure, locked chests, golden caches, etc, gigantic 34 levels to explore! non-linear exploration - finally you have to ask yourself "Where to next?"Only small downside I experienced: Backtracking in order to search for something left out or testing a theory to a puzzle was sometimes hindered by hoardes of monsters guarding ares, which were already cleared out. This makes grinding possible to an extent, but was occasionally also quite time-consuming. Also, in my opinion the main story itself provides limited "replayability" since it's just not nearly as satisfying anymore if you already know where all the secrets are. I hope that the level-editor will result in some great fan-made additional content!Difficulty LevelThe game provides plenty of possibilities for the player to choose their own challenge. Five races, eight classes and 16 skills are paired with the need to form a specialized party of up to four characters. Three different difficulty settings govern the speed and thrill of the very dynamic combat system. As an Old-School RPG veteran I chose to play at the highest difficulty and preferred to draw my own maps instead of enabling the game's automap feature. Additional options exist to raise the challenge even higher. I was very happy to experience a higher difficulty setting not only in terms of more incoming damage and less output, but rather mainly in an increase of the combat's pace. I also didn't get stuck in an unfair combat situation, although different situations did often require to adapt one's strategy, which I highly appreciate in a game.Some puzzles were really challenging, having me ask my partner and roommates for advice and inspiration. I'm proud that I never used help from a guide or an internet discussion; with a reasonable amount of creativity it is possible to solve all of the riddles. Hardly any of the harder puzzles is story-relevant, so there's also the option of moving on and returning later to loot that particular room of booty.AtmosphereI mainly played in a candlelit room on a wall flat screen wearing headphones. I was often able to locate secret passages by the sounds of monsters behind walls. I could always tell from the direction of the sound in which corridor that blasted zombie was currently looking for me. On more than one occasion I heard myself scream in surprise or even fear when suddenly I realized some monster sneaked up on me! I highly recommend playing this game with an adept surround sound system! ConclusionIf you love hack'n'slay games, online raiding parties, bragging about your new epic item in front of your friends and skipping story and text in favor of action, this game is NOT for you!If you are an arachnophobiac, musophobiac, herpetophobiac, necrophobiac, nyctophobiac, hylophobiac, eremophobiac, ophidiophobiac or potamophobiac, this game is DEFINITELY not for you!If you like games emphasizing social interaction, telling a detailed, pre-cut and pre-chewed story or featuring a lot of spoken dialogue, you might consider asking yourself if you can do without any of this. If not, don't play it, you'll just be disappointed.To anybody else: By all means, give it a try! Chances are even if-unlike me-you don't find your next favourite video game, you will be having a great time on the beautiful Isle of Nex!

content:
Posted: March 24, 2015
 An overview for those unfamiliar with the "Dungeon Master" genre Shipwrecked!  Your band of four mysterious prisoners just washed up on a mysterious island, run by a mysterious master.  Fight enemies both mysterious and non-mysterious, and find mysterious items from mysterious chests by solving mysterious puzzles.If you've never played a game similar to this in the past, you're going to feel a bit confused, and perhaps turned off at first.  Although the game is concidered first-person, think of it like this - you are a floating camera, right in front of four party members.  That's right, you control all four.  Even more jarring for many will be the grid-based movement and combat.  The levels certainly don't appear much like grids, mut you move from grid-space to grid-space without any leeway.  No diagonal moves - only forward, back, and 90-degree turns.  This is one of my only complaints - it's restricive,  seemingly an un-neccisary "old school" feature, and sometimes makes me a little dizzy if I start making too many turns.  Controls are mostly menu based, requiring you to click on the weapon of a party member to attack and actually have non-weapon items (like alchemy equipment or warhorns) if you want to use them.  The games has a very nice map system which creates a classic grid-paper like map (nothing is labled for you, if you want to make note of something the game gives you the tools to do so)You would expect, concidering the grid system, that combat would be turn based.  Nope.  You'd better get used to the system quickly, because strafing and dodging opponent attacks are often vital tactics for survival.  This game is quite challenging at times, and I often find that I feel under-leveled for the area I'm in, even when I'm actually not.Character progression is handeled quite well - you never feel completely satisfied with your characters, which is how it should be.  Skills only have 5 levels, but you only get one point per level, and there is something like 20 skills.  Character classes actually feel different from one another and many have very unique benefits / systems.  Alchemists actually grow more herbs once they're in their inventory.  Magic users are treated to a magic system that involves combining different elemental runes to create spells.The environments are absolutely beautiful - this is possibly the nicest looking game I own, in my opinion.  But I'm a sucker for AA, so opinions may vary.  Everything is essentially open world.  The best comparison would probably be metroid, if only because most areas are blocked off by locked doors, the keys to which can only be found elsewhere.  That elsewhere is probably blocked off by some puzzles.  The puzzles are a nice level of difficulty, vague enough to leave you scratching your head, untill you figure them out, at which point you facepalm.And did I mention - you can make and download custom dungeons, some of which are campaign lenth?  It's a wonderful feature that adds huge amounts of value if you want to keep playing after you've finished the original campaign.  -Important Note-In the Windows version, custom dungeons are held in Documents\Almost Human\Legend of Grimrock 2\Dungeons.  Dungeons downloaded from the Steam Workshop are immediately brought there, but there are others on the Nexus which are too large to be allowed on the Workshop.  Place those dungeons in the aforementioned file as well.  Took me forever to figure that out.

content:
Posted: October 26, 2014
												A significant improvement over the first, LOG2 still retains it's almost brutal difficulty curve while progressing through the old-school dungeon crawler environment. If your key driver in an RPG game such as Skyrim is in its graphics, then you will be sorely let down by the presentation of LOG2. That's far from saying the game isn't pretty - but its more functional in appearance than blowing you away with graphical awe.Where LOG2 scores very highly is in both character progression and feeling forever in fear of every creature that comes your way. Your original band of four ship-wrecked prisoners are woefully under-skilled and lack any form of equipment. In fact, you literally start with nothing other than a washed up branch nearby to begin with.There are the usual race-to-class pros and cons. Amongst my group, I created a minotaur barbarian with high strength and attack. A female knight who has attained the ability as the groups' main potion maker sits alongside - protecting my much weaker reptilian rogue and my insectoid wizard at the rear. However, they all have their own unique roles to play in the group - and this is one of LOG2's big strong points. Skyrim's multi-skilled/multi-talented lead role is definitely not seen here. Your heavy hitters dish out damage and also attempt to absorb it - while the brain-boxes lie in second file and do their work from a safe distance.LOG2 is a massively cerebral game. You can stand still for minutes at a time without concern of being attacked. It rewards lateral thinkers - those that think slightly out of the box and who attempt to intelligently work through a puzzle, rather than bash and kill their way through it.Some puzzles are easy - while some are extremely tough to work out. But LOG2 provides a highly rewarding and enjoyable quest as you push on ahead. At the time of writing, I was approximately 8 hours into it - and I'll definitely be seeing this game through to the end.For all those who want more of a thinking player's RPG - you certainly can't go wrong with this.9/10

content:
Posted: October 15, 2014
												Dungeon crawling in the style of Eye of the Beholder at its modern finest.  A fantastic sequel to the first legend of Grimrock.  Almost everything from the original returns, and almost everything has been improved upon.  The developers have spared no effort to improve upon the foundation set in the first game.  Let's start with building a party.  There is significantly more depth this time around.  This new game has 8 classes up from the original 3, 5 races up from the original 4.  But it doesn't end there.  Tool tips provide more information.  Classes no longer lock you to a set of 6 specific skills.  Rather, there are 16 total skills that you are able to choose between to customize your character how you see fit.  You want a frontline knight who also can cast a poison bolt here or there?  Done.  The number of options also leads to a large number of interesting choices.  Sure, an insectoid has great mental stats making for a natural wizard.  But they can also get superior armor, making them easily able to play the tankiest of tanks.All these options will warm the hearts of anyone that loves to get deep into the numbers.  While I find building a party great fun, don't worry if that is not your cup of tea.  The game provides a default party that you can use, and it doesn't take a lot of work to make a barbarian that focuses in strength, damage, and more strength.  As an aside, the character portraits have gotten a major and much needed overhaul.  Your party will look much better than last time around, guaranteed.Once you have a party you are dumped on an island.  Filled with common pirate tropes the designers do a good job of pulling you in, with a steady stream of monsters, loot and puzzles that all gradually increase in strength.  The monsters are a major improvement over Grimrock 1.  There is a greater variety right out of the gate.  In addition this game has added memorable boss encounters, something the first game in the series lacked.  The environments too are more varied, adding above ground areas to the strictly dungeoneering of the first game.  And the maps are much larger.There are new options and attention to detail everywhere.  There are now day and night cycles.  You can dig for treasure.  Combat now includes firearms and dual wielding.  New kinds of puzzles.  Larger variety of weapons and improved weapon descriptions.  Tons of new loot.  You will need all of your new toys to succeed, because like the first one combat can be tough for the unprepared.Top to bottom this game is an improvement over the original.  This is a modern take on classic dungeon crawling that is very satisfying for fans of the genre.10/10

content:
Posted: November 2, 2014
												A superb game - improves upon the first game with brilliance and grace.In particular: - the RPG elements are smooth and highly flexible, allowing you to create quite diverse and powerful characters according to your playstyle. There are a wide variety of items available, with many interesting choices.- the puzzles are wonderfully satisfying and logical, and there is nothing better than that moment where you work out a puzzle you have spent ages on; even if you have those 'ohhhh why didn't  i think of that sooner' moments when you realise how logical it actually was. Some puzzles are really difficult (well at least to me), and one or two I have had to seek help on - there is no shame on occasion! :)Make sure you bear in mind that the game is grid based (in terms of how your party and enemies move around) in true old school fashion - I find this to be a positive feature, but others may not. For some reason one or two people have bought it without checking the nature of the game - all power to the grid! :)The game is far more 'open world' than the first game, allowing for exploration a little more than you might expect. You may find yourself going back and forth the same places a few times over some distance potentially. This is not necessarily a negative depending on how you see it, but I've seen it presented as such so I thought to mention it. Regardless, while it is sometimes irritating to go back and forth it is a very minor thing - the game rewards you for exploration and patience.If you like puzzles, RPG's and don't mind dying a fair few times as you learn (in a satisfying way) then this game is for you.Enjoy!!Oh, and beware the crabs!! ;P No seriously, beware! haha

content:
Posted: October 24, 2014
												As a fan of the first LoG, I may be predisposed to enjoying this game. It takes me back to my childhood playing Ultima Underworld on my Uncle's computer when I would visit. So many hours spent enjoying that game in my younger years, and now so many hours spent enjoying this game in my adult life. The game is a fantastic "old-school" rpg dungeon-crawler. A spirtual successor to those Ultima games (and obviously the successor to the first LoG). I have about 50 hours played under my belt and am only on my second play through. The game is lengthy if you are interested in fully exploring the game. Searching walls for secrets, finding special gear, collecting achievements. The combat is great, and although relatively simple in some ways, some different enemy mechanics force you to switch up combat styles often. There are several different player classes and roles to choose from, so you can format your raiding party to your desire. There are an endless amount of combinations available considering the multitude of skills, races, and talents. I have heard some negative feedback concerning the replay value of this game, though I am not personally seeing that. I have completed the game once, and have now begun my second play through with a different group composition, and although I know where many of the zones/paths/secrets are, the game feels fresh playing with a different group. I have not even begun to look at the user created content yet, though I will be getting to that. All in all, if you are a fan of dungeon crawling RPGs, then you will not be disappointed with this game. At an incredibly fair price for the play value (as I said, 50 hours in now, and I paid ~$13 for it) this game has an large amount of RPG elements to enjoy. This is a MUST PLAY, and at the current price, don't even both waiting for a sale, just grab it now and get crawling.

												You know those games that come out and feel good, feel right, and play right, but they juuuuuuuuuuuuuust don't have the scope, polish, or the design in a few facets quite right to really work, but so damn enjoyable and honest and true in their aim that you like the game and wish the devs the best on the next adventure? That was Grimrock 1.And you know that NEXT game, that takes the scope, polish, and design critiques and sends that sequel thru the roof with some of the best-thought out gaming you've experienced and an all-time classic? THAT'S Grimrock 2.They did so much so right in this game.A grander scale with a whole island full of smaller dungeons to explore. More puzzles. More secrets. More variety. More ambience. More choice. More monsters. More loot. More boss fights. More MORE.It's a much more stabler adventure, with fewer bugs and those were squashed within two weeks of launch. And on top of that, Almost Human fixed the skill system with a PROPERLY simpler one. No more meaningless maxed Spellcraft bonus; everything having 5 tiers and everyone having access to every school makes for some crazy min-maxing and "sure, why not?" class ideas like Fighters who have high INT and spam magical special weapon attacks to complement 1's single example of dual tomahawkin' Mino Rogues. It's fun!

												I grew up with the original Wizardry, which had two colors (black and white), and the UI was basically up+down arrow to select attack options or selling at town. You could move in four directions only, and every 'cell' was a simple box outline with white being the wall edges. I loved it.Legend of Grimrock 2 uses the same four directional movement, but in a modern crafted world. The first game was confined to a giant dungeon, but this one spreads out over multiple themed areas, and many dungeons. Enemy movement and combat has been improved also. Solving puzzles is as important to gameplay as actual battle in LoG2, and what sets it apart. It is satisfying to figure a puzzle out, and often rewarding with good gear. Almost like a Myst game with a combat side; or if you are an older gamer like me, bliss.

												New content. Much game. So pretty. Much wow. The expanded content, works well. The large scope of the island. Is intimidating. But the plentiful amount of food, shifts much of the mood of barely suspended dread, into a more casual, explore and adventure game. If you didn't play the first, I'd still very much recommend it. In fact, I'd go so far, right now, after 7.5 hours, as to say that it's a better game. More coherent, and more atmospheric.I don't mind the square layout of the environment, and a few of the areas are incredibly claustrophobic, simply from atmosphere. You can still make simple mistakes that get you killed. And sometimes pushing a button in the middle of a dungeon or area, can dramatically shift the mood right back to horror. I think the best way to enjoy this game is to play something like 5-15 hours, on normal or easy, just to get a feel for the new challenges. Then, restart, and choose at least one of the "2nd Wave" like options. These options, if memory serves, affect the regeneration crystals, and quick saving. Definitely helps to shift the mood back to the lost / isolated / tragic ambiance of the first game.

content:
Posted: December 28, 2015
												Getting lost in this huge and varied world is so great. Even in the age of Witcher 3, this game shows that grid-based movement can still be fun. I have a hard time explaining why but here are some possible factors:- Enemies feel more menacing because you can't circle-strafe them, play with aggro range or exploit pathfinding bugs against them like in most free movement rpgs/fpss. So the dungeon feels more claustrophobic and menacing... I definitely don't feel that in Skyrim dungeons.- Mapping out the dungeon square by square and paying close attention to your environment for secret buttons and switches feels great, and it's not the typical modern RPG experience. A free movement game can hardly hide a button somewhere on a wall and expect you to find it, here with the constrained views it works.- The grid system allows for some very smart puzzles, I have to admit I sometimes give up and consult a walkthrough, but I enjoy their presence nonetheless!And you get to control (read: juggle) 4 characters, so four times the RPG goodness!All in all, you'll like it if you liked old-school RPGs like Dungeon Master, Eye of the Beholder and Lands of Lore: Throne of Chaos. But if you haven't played those games you should try it anyways! You might very well find that grid-based movement is a bit like pixel art: originally born of technical limitations, it can still bring a unique and interesting twist to a game.

content:
Posted: October 25, 2014
												LoG2 is a Tile Based, First Person, Dungeon Crawling, Puzzler (with combat.) I put the combat in parenthesis because while it is a prominent aspect of the game throughout, it is clearly not the focus of the game, which is the puzzle solving. The puzzles themselves get harder as the game progresses. If this is your first exposure to this type of game, it's likely that you'll find it relatively difficult as the puzzles do ramp up in difficulty rather quickly. Being a sequel I imagine that the devs are expecting that the majority of their players will have played the first LoG game in which the puzzles are generally easier and ramp up slower.So now that I've covered what the game is, let's get into some nitty gritty.The gameplay itself builds off of the first one, taking the core of the game and maintaining what it was, while making some distinct improvements based off player feedback from the first game. Monster AI has been improved so that monsters will try to counter squared dancing tactics (these are still effective, but sometimes need to be modified a bit based on what you are fighting). Monsters will also sometimes try to lure you to where they can hit you or even just wait you out instead of charging to their certain demise when you're hiding around a corner waiting to ambush them.Each monster has it's own unique mechanics for how it moves and fights, requiring the player to learn the best ways to fight each one. Some monsters will leap behind the player, or steal your stuff right out of your hands, while others will actively dodge your attacks by jumping back a tile, etc. This is a distinct improvement from the first game where monsters were mostly the same, just moving from tile to tile to attack you as directly as they could and only flanking you by accident, now when they flank you it's on purpose. There are also several boss fights in this game unlike the first game that really only had 1 boss at the end of the game. Each of the boss fights feels like a puzzle in and of itself because of having to figure out how best to approach the fight. Not going to go into any more detail than that on them though as I don't want to give away any spoilers.The dungeon crawling experience has been enhanced as well with the introduction of the great outdoors, with a full day and night cycle, with some things happening based on the time of day or night. The first game was entirely indoors, on top of that it was highly claustrophobic with narrow halls and low ceilings. Lo♥♥♥♥nswers that by giving you multiple tiers of vertical movement on the same level and the openness of being able to be outside and see through the space between trees. About the multiple tiers, this adds an entirely new dimension to the game because this opens up the possibility for bridges that you can go over and under, pits you can drop down into and climb back out of, and ledges you can get up onto, all without changing to another map just because you went higher or lower than 'ground level' for the map you are on.The original races were kept along with the addition of a new race, the ratlings. They also added classes, but with characters being centered around their skills, the classes are fairly fluid, offering advantages in the skills that the class would be good at but not really penalizing you if you decided to let say a barbarian learn to be a mage, or if you wanted a wizard to be able to wear heavy armor and stand on your front line. This opens up the party options and makes it so that there really is no 'bad' party composition. While some parties might be easier to play than others, any party can be made to work. This makes random party generation an interesting optional mechanic that you can take advantage of to give the game a bit more replayability.The skills have also been refined since LoG1 so that each point in a skill is significant, making you noticeably better with that skill each time you add a point. Plus at certain points in skill development you gain additional perks, such as dual wielding light weapons, so that when you swing one light weapon it doesn't put both on cooldown, just the one you swung.The story itself is 'hidden' within the game. You start off knowing nothing more than that you are shipwrecked and washed up on a beach. The story itself is delivered to you with that in mind, where you find notes written by the master of the island to you as his only real way of communicating with you, and you also find notes and other things left behind by others who were here before you, leaving the mystery of what fate befell them. The game's story stands by itself, without needing you to have played the first game, but players that have played the first one may notice small links back to it hidden on the island implying a deeper connection between the island and Grimrock than one might naturally suspect. That being said, while there is a story present, it is clearly not the focus of the game, which is the dungeon crawling itself and most of your experience is motivated by simply needing to survive on the island.The game has a lot of secrets hidden throughout, most of which are found by discovering ways to access optional areas of the game. These hidden areas often contain powerful items that will have a significant impact on the game, but at the same time, none are absolutely necessary to progress through the game, they only make it a little easier to do so. Everything you absolutely have to have to progress through the basic game and get to an ending is offered in plain sight without the need for discovering secrets. I definitely don't recommend not looking for the secrets though as they will help immensely.And finally, when you are done with the core game, or just want to pound your head against something different for a while, there is a dungeon editor included with the game so that players can make and publish their own content using the features included with the game and some ability to add in entirely new stuff. (I wont be going into detail on the features and capabilities of the editor in this review though as I have yet to play around with it).Final verdict:A worthy successor to the first Grimrock game that kept what made it great and enhanced what needed to be enhanced. A very good example of what the old school, tile based, dungeon crawlers are, and well worth the play if you enjoy the genre. Obviously not good for you if you aren't a fan of this type of game which spent about a decade in hibernation before the first Grimrock awoke the sleeping dragon... or cube as the case may be.

content:
Posted: October 16, 2014
												This is the very first game that I've pre-ordered and when I did that, I was pretty sure that it was going to worth it.I couldn't be more right.This game, like Legend of Grimrock 1, is an old-school dungeon crawler in which you create a party with four characters and...well crawl through dungeons :) But this time, the game is built on a HUGE area which covers both above and under ground areas. I'll be comparing this with LoG 1 but you'll get the idea even though you haven't played the first game.1-) I loved how day and night cycle of the world. First game takes place in an underground dungeon so the player has no idea whether it's day or night time. 2-) There are more classes and a whole new skill system. I don't know whether you'll like the new system or not but I think it's simple and elegant with 5 skill levels and milestones that provides you with additional abilities (for example; you get dual wield (yes we have dual wield option now) ability at 3rd level of light weapon skill.3-) In my opinion the game is way harder than the first one, but in a nice challenging way. Also the puzzles seem to be more sophisticated and somehow makes you feel like a genius when you solve them.I think these are the main differences of LoG 2. If you liked playing the first game or interested in old-school RPGs than this game is an awesome pick for you.Note: The date of this review is 16.10.2014 and the game is out for a day now. I'm saying this because there are some technical optimization problems with the current state of the game (like it has low frames at some areas) but I think this issue will be fixed with updates at a later date. Check this if you are reading this at a future time.

Posted: October 16, 2014
												This is the very first game that I've pre-ordered and when I did that, I was pretty sure that it was going to worth it.I couldn't be more right.This game, like Legend of Grimrock 1, is an old-school dungeon crawler in which you create a party with four characters and...well crawl through dungeons :) But this time, the game is built on a HUGE area which covers both above and under ground areas. I'll be comparing this with LoG 1 but you'll get the idea even though you haven't played the first game.1-) I loved how day and night cycle of the world. First game takes place in an underground dungeon so the player has no idea whether it's day or night time. 2-) There are more classes and a whole new skill system. I don't know whether you'll like the new system or not but I think it's simple and elegant with 5 skill levels and milestones that provides you with additional abilities (for example; you get dual wield (yes we have dual wield option now) ability at 3rd level of light weapon skill.3-) In my opinion the game is way harder than the first one, but in a nice challenging way. Also the puzzles seem to be more sophisticated and somehow makes you feel like a genius when you solve them.I think these are the main differences of LoG 2. If you liked playing the first game or interested in old-school RPGs than this game is an awesome pick for you.Note: The date of this review is 16.10.2014 and the game is out for a day now. I'm saying this because there are some technical optimization problems with the current state of the game (like it has low frames at some areas) but I think this issue will be fixed with updates at a later date. Check this if you are reading this at a future time.

												This game disappointed me. The first LoG is fantastic. The big difference between the two is that while in LoG you almost always could progress to the next level, and the really crazy puzzles were for secret stuff; in LoGII the crazy puzzles are in the way all the time. content:
Posted: March 26, 2016
												The "modern execution" of this "oldschool" game modernizes all the wrong things.  The combat is real-time but movement is still grid-locked and the perspective still first-person, so you will be wasting precious seconds spinning in place to get turned the right way while your enemies get free hits in; ruining any sense of "action" or "realism" that real-time combat should normally create.It's the spell interface that really ruins the experience, though.  Picking out the correct order of nondescript runes that cast a spell might be (at best) a cute mechanic in a better game than this one, but when you're forced to do it in the middle of (already kludgey) real-time combat for every spell you will ever cast, it feels much more like you're fighting the game than the actual monsters.It's a horrible mix of combat elements on par with the likes of Final Fantasy XIII.  Except that game was at least playable.

												Man, I'm really trying to like it, and I'm going to keep trying, but I just can't bring myself to enjoy this.The combat is similar to LoG 1, but enemies are much tougher. Not in a difficult way, but in a tedious way. It takes way too many hits to kill even the most basic of enemies and it gets boring after a few hours.The above-ground island portion isn't really that great. I think they were going for an open world kind feel, but it doesn't work. I only find myself having fun when I go underground to the dungeons, but those parts don't last nearly as long as I'd like. The Puzzles aren't great. They're either too simple, have a stupid solution involving searching the walls for a hidden button, or require an item you don't have yet. Or maybe you missed it all the way back, you have no way of knowing.There's no real sense of doom like in Grimrock 1. Then, I had no idea how far down I was or what was next. Now I just find a puzzle, see if I can solve it, and if I can't I look for a dungeon. They try to replicate the mysterious story of Grimrock 1 by adding the Island Master, but it's not as interesting or thrilling. "Ooh some dude brought you to his spooky island with monsters and traps, scary..." Reminds me of the first live action Scooby Doo movie.Like I said, I'm going to keep trying because I loved Grimrock 1 so much, but I'm having a lot of trouble enjoying this one and I can't give it a positive review.

content:
Posted: February 5
												Brutally difficult, and not in a good way.I played through the game on 'Normal' - heaven help anyone who chooses a higher difficulty level. The start feels relatively gentle, and adventuring around the island is fun for the first couple of zones, but before very long the difficulty ramps up to a frustrating degree. You're encouraged to sidetrack to other areas if the one you're in is beyond your current level, but there's very little indication what would be suitable (and at multiple points I was finding that there wasn't anywhere that was a suitable level for me to go).The game seems to be designed for frustration. Dealing with multiple enemies at once is a near impossibility; the only way to deal with most of them is to kite them away and dance around them in an open area, and in many cases if you find yourself surrounded it's almost guaranteed to mean having to reload. And that's before we get to enemies like the mosquitoes (which appear in large groups, have high evasion to melee attacks, and melt your health if they surround you... which they will), fire elementals (which appear after certain quest triggers, charge at you before you have time to react and two-shot three members of your party... and again, always come in groups), and the petrification mechanic  (kind of like an instant death, only with this one you can't even revive with potions). I like where it went with some of the puzzles, but the way everything gels together it was quite a frustrating experience overall. I'd be hard-pressed to recommend it on, to be honest.

												Grimrock gives you the same feeling as Myst. They both give you a wonderful journey of discovery into a weird but internally consistent world with great puzzles. Overall, it's a wonderful, wonderful experience.I have my gripes, though. The game is delightfully hard, as in challenging, but also stupidly hard. You'll also die a lot because there aren't any hotkeys nor any pause button and you have to click really fast through inventory menus. The game math is opaque, counter-intuitive and unbalanced. Did you know that wizards are worse at being wizards than the hybrid wizard/figther class? Did you know that weapon damage becomes irrelevant to how much damage you deal in the second half of the game? Did you know that firearms are useless? Etc. Etc. Maybe the game can be balanced through patches.Overall, a really great game with some really big frustrations. Maybe the smart choice is to wait until 2015 or 2016 for it to be patched up.

content:
Posted: October 26, 2014
												Legend of Grimrock II offers a compelling experience between exploration, a minimalist but endearing story and pretty decent graphics. This sequel manages to cross its own style with a Myst-like experience, where you end up on an island and have to figure everything out. The freedom of movement within the island is quite enjoyable : will you keep trying this dungeon with tough enemies but greater rewards or will you come back to it once you've leveled up a bit ?The leveling, fighting and magic systems are okay but show their limits around the two thirds of the game. Once you've discovered most of the good stuff and figured out most spells, the game becomes really repetitive. The fact that the fights tend to pile up in the end made me wish the game was shorter, just so I'd be done with it. Apart from this end game tediousness, the clever riddles and the rich exploration are enough to justify playing it.

content:
Posted: November 13, 2014
												Intro: For me, Legend of Grimrock 2 came out of nowhere. I didn't ever expect a sequel to the first game, but when I saw it I picked it up based on how good the first game was. If you are new to Grimrock or new to Dungeon crawling games I recomend playing the first Game. The original game is slower and teaches you the basics much better than its faster cousin.Gameplay: Much like the first game, you have the same style of dragging and dropping for inventory management. Clicking on characters weapons to attack and drawing patterns in the runes to cast spells. Navigating the menus can be clunky if your in a pinch, but if you use the numbered hot keys you shouldn't have a problem. Puzzles: Puzzles are a big part of Dungeon crawling games. The puzzles in Grimrock 2 are weaker than the first game. Most of the time with puzzles you won't even know there is anything to solve. The game progresses along until you hit a brick wall and are stuck. And unless you did a super specific thing the game didn't elaborate on you will be stuck. The puzzles are challenging don't get me wrong, but when you don't receive enough information to know there is a puzzle to solve, it's frustrating.Open World(Not really but we will call it that): Unlike The first Grimrock, the second opens the player up to a bunch of areas really fast. Much like Dark Souls, going to areas you are not prepared for will get you killed. The "open world" gives the player a sence of exploring foreign lands and although the back tracking sucks, it makes the player learn the island and get familar with it as their home.Random thoughts: This game is exactly as it looks: Challenging, fun, and thought provoking. Prepare your internet browsers, because some of these puzzles are random af. Involving time of day, standing in certain spots for periods of time or digging multiple times. Conclusion: All in all its a good buy for a fan of the  genre or franchise. If your new to these kinds of games, wait for a sale and pick up the first game. content:
Posted: November 1, 2014
												Let me start off by saying I may complain a bit in this review but I still recommend this game.  Also these are just my opinions of the game, I am sure there are many people who will say "well I did not experience these problems blah blah blah"  what I am saying is don't be butthurt by my opinion this is just what I have experience and felt for myself.Cons- Some puzzles are highly frustrating or very cryptic while I enjoy difficult puzzles some are extremely hard to decifer which can lead to frustration in people new to this type of game.Some classes seem good but in reality they are not take the knight his dodge increase with shields is broken or at least it looks broken to me (will be patched if it is im sure)Was not impressed with the alchemist guns there never seemed to be enough ammo and the guns were scarce. Potion making was awesome though.Exploration was very fun in the beginning but later on it got very frustrating (for me).Spells seemed weak IMO at times they would hit hard but most of the time even if the monster was weak to it they seemed over all weaker from the last game.Characters seem to miss allot even if you get accuracy up until you get into the upper levels of accuracy.Monsters can hit you over and over and over at times while you wait to recharge your characters attacks.Near the end the boss fights just throw enemies at you which is not very fun they could have done something different with the boss fights to make them more interesting.Puzzles get a little tedious after awhile because they are mostly just redos from previous puzzles with little differences.Underwater battles are irritating especially if you don't have a trident or spear.Not a whole lot of enemy variation.I felt there were not a whole lot of weapon variations either but this may be nitpicking.No voice acting from the master of the island (I feel a mysterious voice talking on his notes and maybe a random sentence when sleeping or something would have been awesome).I know that most of the story is figured out with stone heads and notes from the island master but I feel at times besides looking for a way off the island you really didn't know why you were exploring the areas looking for power gems.Armor sets do not have set bonuses so finding them all is good but doesn't make much of a difference.ProsI like the night and day cycle especially for some of the puzzles.weapon special attacks were pretty good.graphics looked good.(not that this really should count for scoring a game.)Level design was great in most areas and it kept it fresh to have different level designs.Most puzzles were fun to solve.Map in this game is extremely helpful so is the compass and watch.The armor sets looks cool even if they didn't get set bonuses.Each enemy had unique attacks (don't drop the ethereal dagger)Sound effects were done very well.Potions made are very useful.For the price lots of hours of gameplay especially with workshop dungeons and such.Good unique character races with good pros and cons to using them.While I enjoyed this game I also got much more frustrated with this one, way more than I did with the first one which is very very awesome (mine is owned from Good old Games and not in my steam account). By the time I got to the end of this game I was ready for it to be over, maybe I should have taken a break from it but it was interesting enough that I wanted to finish it.  I will be taking a long break from it and then downloading allot of workshop dungeons when they become available and I feel like playing some more.Graphics 7/10Sound  8/10Combat 5/10Gameplay 7/10Story 4/10Replayability 9/10Final score 6.6 or 7 rounded up definately worth getting.

												So Ive had this game for some time, and Ive playe dit, then stopped, played it again, stopped,, and yet again. I ask myself why I keep stopping my play through every time I delete this, and the same answer comes up. Its tedious and boring. Grimrock one was a favorite of all of my games. Very classical style of gaming. In grimrock two its all about moving around attacking then repositioning. Not a big deal if you have room to work with. The problem isnt the combat.The problem with this game that Ive found is that you NEED to use guides for a good portion of the puzzles. "But why? Shouldnt you be able to figure them out on your own? Thats the point of a Puzzle game." I would think to myself. Yes, it would be, if a good portion of these puzzles actually had tangable and relivant clues to solving them. A majority of them are reduntant. Per example: The Glyph Room. You all too often will see a stone face shooting a projectile. And all too often will see stone plates on the floor. You get no hint. Just the room name. How would you even know that you are supposed to draw out the spell on the floor that is being cast from the shooting wall-head? You wouldnt. You get no hints about it, and no relivant clue anyplace. Another example "The Silent one has a friend. Head east into the sun." Alright...which takes you directly into a tree one step later from that point once you find the Silent Statue head that says ... That paired withthe fact most dungeons, unlike Grimrock 1, have only one way through them in addition to needing to find some obscurecrack in the wall to open a secret door make this game nearly unplayable without looking for clues and spoilers online. I didnt enjoy this half as much as Grimrock 1. It just wasnt that good. The story isnt even there if you are looking for one. You were prisoners on a ship...some magic magnet pulled your ship ashore. You begin the game. All you know is some♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥running the place is a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ that likes to leave you notes about how hes a♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ Thats your story. Nothing else to it.Cant say I recommend this game over Grimrock 1. The puzzles alone are annoying and only make sense to the creator of them, rather than the player. The maps are♥♥♥♥♥♥ and mostly a cluster♥♥♥♥ of come back later, the games plot lacks, one way dungeons, and enemies with far too many HP even with skilled adventurers and powerful weapons. Play Necrodancer, youll be playing the same♥♥♥♥♥♥here just with less reward.

												I didn't like the first one, but figured I would give it a chance; see if they improved any of the things I didn't like. They did not. If anything, it's worse than Grimrock I. content:
Posted: October 16, 2014
												I am going to start this review of by saying one simple sentence before i get into the Nitty Gritty of why you should buy this game!"This game is my personal GOTY for 2014 and every minute is a imerrsive blast of fun that i don't want to stop"Now onto the review!Firstly I will talk about the points i think make this game EXTREMELY good.- Gameplay- Immersion- Visuals- Sounds- Unique-nessThis game in it's gameplay does something that other games simply cannot capture, from the open worlds of skyrim all the way to one of my personal favourite RPG's (Fallout). What it does is something i don't FEEL in games anymore, it captures feelsing i didn't think a game could make and then encourages me to play the game with the freedom of my own mind.What i mean by this is the game immerses you completely in it's world, It never feels like you are playing a game but you are a crew of prisoners, fighting your way through a beautiful and luxurious island. Every atmosphere feels unique to the game and immerses you in the adventure, you REALLY FEEL like you are on an adventure, not PLAYING an adventure in a GAME. Like i said, i've loved and played many RPG's buy this is one of the few games that have captures a pure, undying sense of ADVENTURE from within me.The gameplay is also something i love, the world feels seamless and connected which helps to support and ecourage you to explore and look for secrets. It's like small open-worlds, this way you can explore a lot and look for every secret - without overbearing amounts of land to cover. It's a game where doing puzzles, finding secrets feels extremely rewarding each time.The combat in this game is what i believe to hit-or-miss, either you will enjoy it or... You will not. It's using an older generation of RPG as inspiration, Q and E to turn, then WASD to move around on a grid. Combat is real time, with a turn based aspect. Meaning you and the enemy attack eachother based on spell and weapon cooldowns. I believe the charm of the game (being the older style RPG) is either hit-or-miss, i myself love it though and it adds a unique charm that no other games capture!My next point is the class and race system, it's executed so well i needn't say much other than you get a good amount of race and classes to build a squad that suits you, everythign plays completely differently than other classes. Later skill building further increases variation to a point where you can do what you want, and play how you want (and if you understand the farmer class, i assume you are a god at this game.)Lastly the sound and visuals, they both work well together with the immersion to create a world that looks realistic enough to tottaly engross you, but still fantasy enough to really give off that old RPG feel. The games graphics are not taxing (but then my computer can handle anything) but still manage to blow me away even more than most recent releases ( *cough* Shadows of mordor *cough* )Overall this game is absolutely a brilliant game, developing it's strengths from the first game and making something near perfect. I have little to no weak points about this game so far and even if i did, i wouldn't bother putting them here simply because they would be as miniscule as; Only skill points and not stat points, or i am bad at puzzles and my brain hurts.Basically you want this game, it's superb, it's fun, it's beautiful and it does one thing i deem most important.It's unique.

Posted: March 29, 2015
												I have played the game for about 6 hours and I am not convinced that it is as good as many people claim it is. I find the control scheme very annoying (needing SIX keys to walk around, and needing to right-click on weapons to use them, let alone using magic which requires numerous clicks -- and all of that in real-time). The enemies are kind-of underwhelming, just standing in front of you and hitting you -- unless you ran into enemies that are far too high-level for you, which can easily happen. There are some pretty annoying puzzles (invisible switches, items that are hidden without the game giving any indication of where you have to look, be-fast-and-move-to-the-correct-spot-or-you-die challenges, and puzzles whjch basically require you to die multiple times before you can actually get a glimpse of what you need to do to solve them). The character upgrades are too rare, and it is too easy to make a mistake in constructing your characters (I made an alchemist who uses firearms, but now I find that firearms and ammo for them are very hard to come by, while I have found fantastic bows with reusable arrows that I cannot use). Fortunately, enemies that are defeated do not return, so that's a plus. But overall, I find the fun factor not so high that I am keen to continue.What REALLY hurts the game is the complete lack of any story. Why are you doing the things that you do? Why do you walk around here? Why not just stay on the beach, build a big fire, and kill turtles for dinner until you are rescued? I don't feel that "exploring for the sake of exploring" is very rewarding. Ultimately, the whole story seems to come down to something like: walk around until you have collected 20 power gems, and then you can unlock the final door. Hooray!I played the first Grimrock for a while, and that game feels much better. There is an actual incentive for you to delve into the dungeon, and the atmosphere is suffocatingly claustrophobic. While in Grimrock II you are just walking through woods without rhyme or reason. The atmosphere of this game is just off.All in all, I am on the fence as far as Grimrock II is concerned. It is not that it is a bad game, it is just not as good as the first one, and I rather play something else than more Grimrock II. So I have to rate it down, partly in compensation for all the up-ratings.

content:

A Paladin’s Review: Legend of Grimrock 2. The Island of Broken Bones and Death TrapsGenre: 1st Person Old-School Tile-based RPG Focused on Combat with Puzzles. Developed and Published by: Almost Human GamesPlatform: Windows, MacOSX and LinuxBusiness Model: Base Game.Copy Purchased by Myself Read the full and unabridged review on A Paladin Without A Crusade[wp.me]PreambleLegend of Grimrock 1 jumped into the indie gaming scene in 2012. It was bringing old school dungeon crawling gameplay to the next generation with better graphics and ideas learned in modern times. It was a success and one of my favorite games of 2012. Fast forward three years later and I finally get the chance to play Legend of Grimrock 2. Its the expanded sequel that brought a new open world experience as well as new monsters, puzzles and challenges to face.Overall Gameplay ThoughtsEschewing its previously more directed experience in a dungeon, Legend of Grimrock 2 takes place on a very large island. The real-time first person tile-based RPG is back with a few new tricks. You now have eight character classes to choose from including magical warriors, alchemists and farmers. There’s a few new races and faces with new skill trees that you’re given far too few skill points to spend into. All of which takes place on an island named….Nex apparently. Your mission is...to...I guess survive on the island and figure out its mysteries. It's not hard to feel like the sequel was where the developers included anything and everything they could just to do it. I put in five hours before I called it a day, fair warning.Story and Atmosphere ThoughtsThe game starts out with an animated CGI cutscene that depicts your group of prisoners getting shipwrecked on an island. An opening scene that is a little jarring (and an unnecessary expense) change from LoG1’s opening scene with still images. Somehow, that cutscene conveyed even less story about why your group of survivors here and what their purpose is. It’s the first sign that the story just isn’t as good this time around. All you really get is the island’s “owner” taunting you with written notes and giant stone face statues giving you cryptic clues and hints about the island as well as what you should do to move on. Neither of which really does it for me this time. Granted, LoG1’s story was pretty light as well but there was something to it that made me want to see what was going on. Here? There’s no reason for me to explore, outside of just doing it for completion sake.It doesn't help that the atmosphere of LoG1 is gone. It’s no longer an old dungeon that has seen far too many people die in it. The soft howling wind, the scratching of enemy’s claws nearby, the sense that danger could be right around the corner, its just not here. Instead, it’s an island of themed areas. You’ve got the graveyard here, the beach there, a giant pyramid over there and a forest behind you, among other areas. When you've got the ocean waters acting as a barrier instead of a solid wall, it breaks the immersion. It's little things like this that hurt the game's experience.Combat PonderingsI said in my previous review of Legend of Grimrock 1 that the combat was balanced on a razor’s edge. If it strayed just a little from that balance, it would cease to be enjoyable. Well, the combat in LoG2 strays. I found myself in combat situations far too many times and against way too many opponents in cramped rooms. Where I would then be easily surrounded and slowly beaten to death in a war of attrition. The only changes to the combat system on your end is improvements to the magic casting system. Which, sure, the magic system is nicer to use. However, the combat system is still largely the same system as before. Circle around enemies, spam your weapons/abilities off cooldown as often as possible and hope the enemies die before your group gets done in. Oh and if you lose anyone, well, you’re going to be done in quickly.Enemies have new AIs (though I noticed that they would often get stuck with indecision) with new moves to avoid the typical strategy of the previous game. Which I would be ok with this change because it would force new strategies to be developed. But then I get quickly surrounded by enemies and killed off because I got stuck in yet another corner with three or more enemies trying to gnaw my face off. I signed up for a game about surviving with my wits and getting through tricky puzzles. I didn’t sign up for a combat spree-a-thon where I slaughter hundreds of enemies in long battles of attrition.Dying in Death TrapsThere are games that pull off death traps well, as part of the experience. You have to be careful how many times you use them, especially if you’re wanting to advance the plot along. I find the most effective ones are death traps used to teach players to be more careful and wary of their surroundings. But LoG2 doesn’t give you the clues to tell you that what you’re about to do is a bad idea. I died at least seven to ten times in five hours from pointless death traps. It’s a ton of trial-and-error gameplay that I got sick of in a real hurry.PC Settings Menu & Optimization ProblemsAll of the settings from LoG1 return and with a few new addition. Windowed, Borderless,  Fullscreen and a good selection of resolution options. V-Sync for which you’ll probably want triple buffering because the screen tearing is hideous otherwise. There’s a new Render Quality slider which substantially changes how good everything looks. Texture resolution, texture filtering, shadow quality and SSAO quality sliders with high/medium/low options. Field of view slider isn’t available but the standard field of view should be fine. Music and sound effect sliders are here with individual mute buttons. Settings wise, it has everything you’ll need.Legend of Grimrock 2 is horribly optimized. Even on the lowest graphical settings, my framerate would tank to 45 FPS just standing around in a forest/desert/beach with no visible enemies nearby. Get some fighting going and it tanks further. It isn’t consistent what will bring the framerate down. Its not even that great a looker. Sure, the underground levels, the creatures and animations look fine. But the outdoor levels? With the trees and plant life? They seem...merely adequate. It’s frustrating though as the game will lag at random times, making travel not nearly as smooth as it should be.Final ThoughtsLegend of Grimrock 1 was a title where less was more. Legend of Grimrock 2 seems to think that more is more. I don't agree. The atmosphere is gone, replaced with themed areas and more frustrating combat. Puzzles just aren’t as satisfying to solve this time around. And exploration? Exploration is hampered by the knowledge that you have to slog through respawning monsters and pointless death traps. LoG2 is a sequel that tries to be bigger and better than what it was, but loses what made the original fun for me in the first place. While I will give some kudos for the magic system improvements, the new classes that add a little bit of flavor to the gameplay and the new monsters with their different attacks, it's not enough for me. As a whole, it isn't the fun I wanted and I'm really disappointed by that. 												The game looks nice and is fairly enjoyable when you can get past the horrible movement mechanics. It is the most obnoxious way to navigate. You're basically locked to a grid for movements and can only rotate 90 degrees. If you click a few directions at once it sometimes (but not always) will make several moves which you cannot abort. The puzzles are okay, basic, and sometimes boring. I feel like there's a lot of really good stuff locked behind some cumbersome mechanics. The combat system is not very friendly. You're clicking all over the place trying to make stuff happen. Sometimes you need to drag and drop and item instead of right-clicking it. It's not always the most relaxing time. I wish I could be more positive about it. If you like the idea of old dungeon crawlers from the 90s where you were locked to a grid for movement, you might really enjoy this one. Good attempt but needs a bit of work if there is a future version.

content:
Posted: April 8
												Legend of Grimrock 2 is a good looking, fun to play and hard to master game. It starts of like any other RPG too - you strand on an island and have to free yourself from a cage. However, the game is slightly different than all the other RPG's: You play a party of 4, while in first person. You can arrange the position of your party members to have meele characters stand in front, ranges in the back [...]  It's a nice, at least for me new and fun concept. However it also has its flaws - but i will come back to that later.The gameplay is basicly you and your party moving around on square tiles, killing monsters, finding treasures, solving puzzles and overall exploring the newly found area. I'ts not a bad thing to do and i enjoyed it! THe monsters are generic, yes, but look great nontheless. The puzzles were okay to solve but still not bad enough to be instantly revealed. Look-wise the game is fantastic. The details are awesome and it ran very smooth on my - for todays standards - okay-ish pc. However, what makes me 'Not recommend' the game is the following: After 1-2 hours of gameplay you meet your first boss. And here is where things start to get bad. Fighting the boss on tiles, with your party arranged to your needs, cooldowns on your attacks, and very limited movability is just horrible. I tried it over and over and over again to be able to beat him, but i just couldnt do it. I was never even close to finishing him off. The slow, limited combat possibilities against a Tentacle boss who can spawn, despawn and attack from anywhere is just not working out! Having such a boss as first 'hard' encounter was demoralizing and frustrating.Unless you like huge challenges like that even on normal difficulty and are a fan of the movement / combat system itself, you might want to think about skipping on this game. Please keep in mind that this is just how i experienced it and how i think about the game. It's really not bad, but i cannot recommend it to the broad majority of user out there.

												Legend of Grimrock 1 was a GREAT puzzle game. It had a certain amount of combat in it, but it was kept to a minimum, and generally you were rarely outnumbered. You could take your time with the combat.Legend of Grimrock 2 seems to have forgotten it's puzzle roots and provide puzzles that are far too easy to solve even for someone who is generally not that into puzzle games, and adds a HEAPLOAD of combat to the game, and also against far more dangerous enemies. Enemies are also much more numerous in this game compared to its predecessor, leading to you being surrounded and slaughtered sometimes in seconds, leading to multiple frustrating reloads in order to handle random battles that you had no chance preparing for.In fact, the random ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t battles is what, in the end, caused me to give up and say good bye to Grimrock 2. I wanted a puzzle game, and was given a dungeon crawler with a subpar combat system instead. After I had finished Crystal Mines and ended up outside with 10+ rat patrols and the rat boss (which I'd already beaten) AGAIN I just had enough. There are so many ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t moments where enemies will spawn out of nowhere or just give you the middle finger saying "Oh, you solved that puzzle did you? Here, have a near impossible battle!"It's just the fact that you have no chance to prepare for these that make it overly annoying and leading to multiple deaths and reloads just to try and get that one "perfect" battle that you actually survive.I was NOT looking for a combat game. I do not recommend Grimrock, in spite of it's graphics, atmosphere and puzzles. It's not worth it.

Posted: February 15, 2015
												Let me begin by saying that some people will like this game a lot.  The artwork is gorgeous, and the combat simple fairly simply to use.  The level-up system has a lot of nice variation without confining you too much.What I don't like:1.  You can only move in one of four directions: N, E, S and W.  Man y of the games challenges, in fact, rely on that rigid tie to a square grid, but after playing games like Elder Scrolls and Fallout 3, I find it disconcerting.2.  Some of the challenges require speed and reflexes that are simply beyond me, and  may be beyond many players.3.  While there's some freedom in where you go, overall the game is pretty linear, with advancing often requiring having found just the right item somewhere else.4.  The greatest sin-- too many of the challenges are "zap you're dead" challenges.  In some cases, the only way to get their measure is to be instantly killed by them.  This may require avoidance henceforth.  In many other cases, the only way to solve them is by advancing until you're killed, but at least see enough of the details to do something else when you restart the game.  Sort of like the Tom  Cruise movie, "Edge of Tomorrow"-- Live, Die, Repeat. Posted: December 1, 2016
												I guess if you played the first game and already know what's going on, it could be good for you.I picked it up without any familiarity to the series.  It's basically a mashup between an old-school square based dungeon crawler and a point-and-click adventure game.Things to note: there are zero visual indicators that anything is important, or that you can interact with anything.  You have 4 "party" members, that all occupy the same square except that their position in the party dictates whether they can or cannot interact with things.The game starts with one of the characters highlighted and basically no indication of what to do (pick up the stick).  However, if you're foolish enough to drop the stick in the hands that are highlighted (or were highlighted when I started the game) you can't actually hit the door - because you're too far away from it.  Had to watch a tutorial video to hit a door with a stick, because the mechanics of party positioning and item usage are left to you to figure out.My wizard died before I escaped the cage, because I had the audacity to click some of my buttons (that have no readout or description as to what they are or do).If you enjoyed older games where you had to click everything on the screen to find something that moves, this is one of those.  Looking around doesn't serve much purpose, since after you release the look button your return immediately to a centered view.  Trying to move where you can't will cause a motion bump - this and the terrible look system will both induce motion sickness if you suffer from it.When I was younger, I enjoyed games like this because there seemed to be a lot of "mystery".  As I've grown more familiar with game design, I've come to realize that this is really just a disguise for a poor, unintuitive layout that eats time via having the user search for interaction.If you want to customize your character, be prepared to play Dungeons and Dragons (TM).  Every character has a sheet with 15-20 skills, a handful of which will get just a couple of points, a few traits and other things that you can pick from.  The classes are thoroughly uninspiring.  Wizard, fighter, fighter wizard.  Don't forget the rogue!I'm sure there are plenty of interesting things to play with in the spells system and lots of things to discover, if you just click enough.
