												I cannot recommend this game. I played the hell out of Eye of the Beholder (all of them) and the other classic D&D games back in the day, and I loved them.That was a long time ago, gaming has come a long way, and I have obligations and responsibilites beyond your little game. So, when the complete lack of autosave/checkpointing causes me to lose 30 mintues of gameplay...I just walk away. Picture it: after a few days of work, I finally have a few minutes to sit down at play. I haven't been thinking about this game for those two days, I haven't had time to think about it, but now I get to play it. So, I sit down with it, spend a few minutes getting my bearings, work out a quick plan of attack, and in I go. I play for a bit, stumble around, maybe fight a few battles, find an item or two...and then die from some ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t. Monster got a lucky crit? ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t pressure plate launch a horde of overpowered enemies at me? Item randomly teleports me into a room full of enemies? Great, now I'm dead; last save was...where I started the session.Look, I understand the *idea* of quicksave (trust me, I lived through it's birth and subsequent abandonment), and I actually fought for it to stay when the checkpoint craze started. But now? There's no excuse for this. Just because you want to pay homage to classic games, this doesn't mean you have to abandon everything we've learned since them.You make me lose my entire play session due to unforeseen ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t while providing no checkpoint or autosave system to mitigate the lost time, I uninstall your game, regret my purchase, and am very uninclined to buy future produces from you. I've purchased both LoG 1 and 2, but don't expect me to buy anything else unless you learn from the past.And this doesn't even get into the awkward UI, bags opening over your character's paperdoll, spellcasting being a giant flipping PITA, having to annoyingly spam clicks during combat (even the classic games had an "all attack" button), the poor-fit outdoor environments are to a strict grid layout, "invisible walls" (why can't my characters just walk around that pillar?), pixel-hunting out the wazoo, and just all-around poor decisions. I wanted to love this game, then I wanted to like it, then I wanted to just power through it, now I want to forget it.

content:
Posted: October 23, 2016
												Just as tedious as the Old School CRPG™s it's emulating. Move around on a big empty grid, exploring a world that is so generic you'd assume every art asset was straight off the shelf. One of the most frustratingly linear experiences I've had this year - go in a line, find two routes: one blocked by Gate A, and one with some monsters and Key A. Going through Gate A leads you to Gate B and a similar hunt for Key B. And so on. "Puzzles" in this game amount to trying to discern what in the game world is a clickable object and what is just a branch or bone on the ground. Prepare to do a lot of clicking. Especially against the monsters, who are HP sponges because the developers realize that their combat system is so laughably awkward (attack, take a step backward so you are invulnerable, wait out the monster's attack, move back, repeat) that they need a huge buffer window to allow chances for the monsters to get a few licks in too. More than anything else, the UI is what made me give up on LoG2. Click on an item on the ground and then click on the character who has to hold it. Then open the character window. Click on the item. Click on the character. Congratulations, you've equipped a branch. Want to swing that branch at an enemy? Right click on a weapon on a character's portrait to attack with that character - no direct binds for this. Spellcasting is even more clunky. Why?The reason it's all so awkward is tied back into the combat. Things actually do get legitimately challenging when several monsters are in the area, or you're in a limited space, but only because of the UI. It takes a lot of mouse movement, clicking, and well-timed strafing as you struggle to open and close inventory windows, swap healing potions from who has them to who needs to use them, click the correct weapons for your attacks, draw little spells on a grid, et cetera. I'm not being coy or cute when I say the real monster in this game is the UI.So, no, the game isn't "too easy", but playing it is boring and awkward and unfun and felt extremely game-y and not at all like an adventure on a strange island. I strongly recommend you play something else. What, exactly, depends on what you wanted to get out of this game.If you like grid maps and RPG combat, parties, and stats, Atlus makes a phenomenal series called Etrian Odyssey for the Nintendo DS and 3DS that is well worth your time. If you like fantasy action combat, Skyrim is the way to go. If you like exploring a mysterious world and solving puzzles, Myst or, more recently, Machinarium are fine options. Just please don't waste your time on this.

content:
Posted: October 19, 2014
												I haven't played the predecessor, so this review is based on the quality of this game as an "old-school" RPG.The game involves a great amount of time tediously scanning walls for very small hidden buttons.  I've spent about a quarter of time in game just retracing steps scanning walls; not my idea of fun.  Finding a hidden button/lever can mean the difference between progressing through content and being stuck at a standstill.  This could have been remedied by allowing the party to comment on hidden features similar to Might and Magic X.Combat was rather clunky, especially playing a wizard.  I found missle weapons to be lackluster, and ranged combat in general was a hassle with projectile collection.  You can effectively kite mobs using melee attacks as long as you are quick enough to move to another tile before giving the mob time to attack.  Additionally, there is no way to track mob health; there are no hit point bars or visual cues.  There is no feedback regarding if a mob is resistant to certain forms of attacks; sometimes skills do 1 damage and then the same skill will do 20 damage (is it because of weak attacks or damage resistance?)  The only methods of healing are via potions and resting.  I made the assumption that one of the schools of magic would contain healing, but that was not the case.  No class healing really detracts from combat.There doesn't appear to be any form of skill reset.  Given that you start the game clueless regarding the skills, items, and spells available, it would be great to have this available in some form.Having played MIght and Magic X, I feel this is an inferior clone.  It does have some nice perks, such as unique weapon skills and interesting puzzles.  Sadly, the game is bogged down by unnecessary tedious tasks and clunky combat/skills.

content:
Posted: November 3, 2014
												The gameplay is clunky, tortured and obtuse along N-S-E-W lines with auto mouse centering. The trailer on the publisher's website is deceptive and misleading as to the game play style. Additionally, it is touted as a "game with an old-school heart but a modern execution". Other than the graphics, there is very little "modern" about this game.This is within the broad ~35 year genre of a "crawler". Much like the word "transportation" (or vehicle) includes many modes of travel, but if Porsche came out with their newest "chariot" lineup, I wouldn't expect for it to be horse drawn. This cart is drawn by a mule.Obviously, my juxtaposition of "Dungeon Crawler" versus "Dungeon Stutterer" was lost on some of prior thread flamers ... this is a "spastic dungeon stutterer" and not a "dungeon crawler" as the term has evolved.It plays more like Adventure on the Atari 2600 ... which was a great game at the time, but I am glad gaming has evolved since then. This one has in theory, but not execution.I was tremendously disappointed.  And yes. I should have known better than to judge the book by its ads, cover. out of context reviews, and video. I should have watched it on twitch or youtube. I didn't... and wasted my money.If you like it, great. Just be warned BEFORE YOU BUY that it has very limited movement, and you might do better with some dice and a scrap of cardboard, burn a stick and write your journey on a cave wall. Seriously, watch it before you buy (and not the developer's deceptive video).1.5 out of 5Namaste.

												I won’t describe the game’s mechanics here as that’s done very well elsewhere (search “Rock Paper Shotgun Grimrock 2” for some well written words on the game). But I will say if you want a game that challenges your lateral thinking as well as your reactions this is a great choice.Having just finished Grimrock 2 my reaction is one of disappointment that there's not more to play. Although there is, of course, as there’s a whole Workshop of levels to check out. I may have a go myself – I’m feeling all inspired :)But the main story mode in this is really very engaging. If you think you’re stuck during the game then try something else, a different area, perhaps. The only gripe I have is that while playing I occasionally felt some of the puzzles were a little _too_ obscure - occasionally relying on assumptions about the players that may not hold true for all or using out-of-game knowledge (or experiences) that not everyone has. But I found ways around that and others may feel that criticism unfair, I’m sure (I’ve avoiding going into details for the sake of spoiler avoidance).This games improves on the first game in so many ways. Although I would encourage you to play the original Grimrock there’s no need to do that other than it’s a gentler introduction to this style of 3D square based RPG.A highly recommended game to challenge brain as well as brawn.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 2, 2015
												Pros: Both combat and puzzles are challenging yet maintain a fresh feel throughout the game. Free roam. The game truly doesn't hold your hand. Hints are plentiful and usually both easy to find and understand. Level editor and custom dungeon support. Game length is around 20 hours on a first playthrough depending on how hard you search for secrets. Plenty of secrets and treasures for you to find and toy with. Many different possible playstyles and party composition. Several bonus difficulty modifiers. Also, normal doesn't feel like easy.Cons: 1v1 combat can be extremely easy once you learn the controls and monster ai. A flying enemy appears that is invulnerable to most types of damage far before most players have the ability to deal with it. Ran into a progress halting bug where a key didn't spawn. Upon reload, the key spawned. This could be a serious issue if a player is using some of the difficulty modifiers. Game design promotes certain party compositions and leaves some playstyles almost worthless. With the amount of available skills, it is disheartening seeing that you can only utilize a few per character due to the low amount of skill points received throughout. Specializing is key to effective party members from the start and there is no way to understand this without playing for several hours. If you are experienced or plan ahead, late game bosses and enemies become a bit easy as damage scaling coupled with potion usage makes for insanely strong builds.Overall, I found this game phenomenal. It steadily increases the challenge both through new variety in monsters and puzzles throughout a lengthy game in a natural way. The music is astounding and boss fights are intense. There are very few cheap traps and most puzzles can be solved quickly if you find and comprehend the hints provided. Secret doors are usually (almost always) audible from the location of the object that opens them so if you pay attention you can find them. If you get stuck, you can go to a different area for most of the game and come back later thanks to the free roam design. Enemies respawn (and get more difficult as your level increases) but it takes a considerable amount of time to the point where I've never seen them respawn in the current dungeon (note that I rarely slept throughout the game though). Progression is consistent and if you get stumped, walkthroughs will make you facepalm because the solution is usually right in front of your face. If you are looking for a challenging, enjoyable, long (compared to modern games), cheap (again compared to modern games), and gratifying game, Legend of Grimrock 2 could be the game for you.

												This is a wonderful contemporary dungeon crawler rpg that manages to retain a retro feel. I had long felt a bit disappointed that these types of games were no longer being made as we moved into the modern age of gaming. I had actually been made aware of this game before the first Grimrock, though I have since purchased the first LoG after finishing this one.The movement might feel restrictive to people who are not accustomed to the genre, however this game is one of the most rewarding experiences I've had playing a video game in years. If you are into a more diablo-like or Skyrim-like experience, you might be a bit frustrated by this game. This isn't exactly a general audience-oriented game. It is certainly pointed at an older generation of gamers, however effectively modernized. It's challenging, it's beautiful, it's about time for these types of games to make a comeback.

												I can't get enough of this game, and it blows me away that it's not a full-blown $50 title. When was the last time you played a game that weaved quick combat and puzzle-solving together in a way that didn't break it up into separate pieces? Where you had to -think- to solve a mystery or open a door, rather than inserting the blue key into the blue keyhole? Where you've had a genuine 'ah ha!' moment that lead to a trove of interesting secrets, literally scattered throughout the game? Satisfying titles like that are just too few and far between.The core of the game revolves around four prisoners trapped on an island following the destruction of their ship. As they begin to explore, they soon come to realize being brought to this monster-ridden island was far from an accident. True to the pen-and-paper nature from dungeon-crawlers of yesteryear, the entire game takes place on a tiled grid, and each step you make moves you from tile to tile as you venture across the island. You can develop and refine your characters to become hardened warriors, gun-wielding rogues, spell-casting wizards, and a number of other fantasy classes (and, by the way, you can import custom character portraits and have your party members be just about anyone you can think of). The combat in the game takes place over this grid that your characters are confined to, and becomes surprisingly diverse once you start to build up spells and abilities. The real core of the game, however, lies in its secrets and its puzzles. There are hundreds of them, over a stunning and surprisingly diverse map. I just can't get enough of it. Folks who really enjoyed that aspect in Morrowind and Skyrim would adore that about this game.If I had to be critical, there's not really much of a story, and for the most part no voice acting whatsoever. I suppose some people might find the grid-pattern of movement annoying, but I found it very helpful with combat. Most of the flaws are completely ignorable for me, with the exception of one or two puzzles being -incredibly- hard. Then again, solving them was also tremendously satisfying.I think most everyone (sans players who're Call of Duty addicts and multiplayer-only gamers) will find something to enjoy here. I'd recommend it even at full price --which I personally think is a steal.

												Okay, first of all, I would like to say that this is a great game, despite some of the criticisms that I have for it. I would recommend that anyone who likes this genre get this game. I can't really imagine anything better for what it is.I'm going to focus on a comparison between this game and the first, and I would, in fact, recommend that you play the first before you play this one. It's a little bit simpler and gives you a better idea of what this game is all about.First of all, some things that this game introduces that I consider positive:--A wide array of different environments:      The original was basically limited to three environments, and they were all dark and dungeony. This game has a huge number of unique ones, all with different themes, including outdoor areas, which give the game a much brighter feel than the original.--A better skill leveling system:     In the original, there were a lot of incentives to run hard in a single direction and level up all of a single skill without touching anything else. This did take away from the excitement of leveling a bit, since almost regardless of the situation, you would be leveling "throwing weapons" or whatever. In this one, it's important to level up a little bit in a lot of different skills, since there are plenty of items that want you to have 1 skill point in air magic or something, and almost every skill gives you a neat perk if you level it up to a certain level. Certainly, the way it is now is much cleaner than it was before, and it's all laid out much more plainly.--Way more items:     Obviously, the second edition was going to have more things, and it does. The wide variety of items makes finding secrets and just generally progressing through the game more exciting, and also lets modded maps take a wider variety of directions.--Multi-layer map structure:     In addition to the classic multi-floor structure of the original game, maps in the sequel have access to ladders and pits, which just generally lets the designers jam more things into smaller spaces. This is another feature that should make map modding a little more interesting.--New race:     This isn't the sort of thing that makes me all that excited, but I know some people will be super into the character creation element of the game, so this is certainly a positive.--Better special attacks:     The combat system has just generally been revamped, and the most noticeable thing to me was that, rather than getting special attacks by leveling the weapon type and just doing it randomly in a fight, you trigger it actively by holding the attack button. A nice touch that make combat a little more interesting.--Better story:     The first Grimrock had a story, but it was fairly secondary to the game itself. Basicaly, you're some adventurers in a mountain trying to find your way out, and that's pretty much the gist of it. In Grimrock 2, you truly feel like there is a goal most of the time, and I'm not going to spoil it, but it certainly adds to the ambiance. And now for the things that are worse than the original:--Open(ish) world:     Don't hate me for putting this in the negative camp, but for this particular game, the world just felt far too big, and in order to do things in the "right" order, players sort of have to get lucky. The problem is that the various areas and dungeons across the map have varying difficulties, and the player has no way to know which are hard and which are easy, so it's fairly easy to poke your head a little bit too deep, and try to take on dungeons which are far too difficult. Another problem with this design is that the game sometimes makes reference to clues hidden in completely different areas, which means that if you encounter the puzzle first, you don't really know what to do, and if you encounter it second, sometimes you've forgotten about the hint that you might have read literally hours ago.--Inaccessible puzzles:     Everyone loves a good puzzle, and for the most part, these were really good, but, like in the last one, there were a few puzzles which you just can't expect for a reasonable human being to be able to figure out, so it's almost impossible to finish the game without cheating and looking on the internet for answers, unless you're a genius.--Really annoying new enemies:     You will notice that for most of the other new content, they were clear upsides. They make modded maps better and spice up the game with new material. It's great to have new monsters to face in your adventures, but in this game, more often than not, I felt that the added enemies were just annoying. From the mosquito swarms that are very hard to hit, to the toads that steal your weapons, to the ice guardians which just generally feel too difficult, to the xeloroids that paralyze your party members, to the medusas that petrify you until you can get to a healing crystal, to the Eyctopusses that blind you, to the Trickster, who seems intentionally annoying, to the air elementals that you can't kill, and finally, to all of the things that poison you and give you diseases. Fighting a lot of the enemies in this game just isn't very fun, and that's linked to the next point.--Injuries really suck     LoG 2 introduces us to a very frustrating combat mechanic: injuries. In battle, your adventurers will sometimes injure some part of their body, which might keep them from casting spells, stop health or energy regen, slow movement speed, or keep you from using your left or right hands. The game honestly didn't need this, and since the only way to fix it is to use healing potions, you basically need someone on hand at all times to make them. By the end of the game, this, combined with the next point, made me use probably more than 100 healing potions.--Boss battles:     Boss battles are a cool idea, but LoG is more of a puzzle dungeon crawler game than an action game, and these just made me feel like there was too much empahsis in that direction. Some of the boss battles were also quite difficult, even on the easiest difficulty, and usually required that I take several healing potions and try several times to beat. The fights should not be the challenging parts of this game in my opinion, but in retrospect, they were. These are the reason that I recommend having someone leveled up all the way in alchemy as quickly as possible, since having resurrection potions and greater healing potions on hand can tend to make the bosses more manageable.Overall, this game was great, and while I did have a lot of negative things to say about it, remember, I was just comparing it the the first, which is a tough thing to beat, and one of my favorite games of all time, so even if I might have sounded a bit harsh, I'm not saying that this game deserves any less than the 92% positive community rating that it currently boasts.

												A worthy successor to the board-like dungeon crawler known as Grimrock I. Both of them seem to hit that sweet spot between making a game look good and leaving things to your imagination. It's tough to describe, but there's just this feeling of charm to it few games have nowadays. Combining old-school gameplay with graphics on par with the Trine series does work out for this one.While the core mechanics remain the same, pretty much every aspect of the game has been expanded upon. No longer are you limited to dungeons, you actually get to explore some outside environments for once. They look daaaamn good too, especially the beach. The new campaign only starts out linear to ease you into things, but after the first two areas you end up in a hub-world from where you choose to go next. There are new puzzles that aren't limited to "put rock on pressure plate", new items, more monsters, more classes, etc. Speaking of items, weapons have special moves now. Also day-and-night cycle.However, I don't think this game would be the same without the editor, which alone is enough to make cool maps. It doesn't take much at all to create your own levels, the editor's fairly simple to use for a 3d game. To make it even better, you can use lua scripts and custom assets to make your dungeon even more interesting. You could create some intricate puzzles, boss fights, or even add your own tiles, objects, and enemies if you have a bit of know-how.What else can I say, I highly recommend LoG2. It's a very solid upgrade from the first game, and even though I'm not even a quarter through, this game satiates my thirst for a chill video game sesh better than Skyrim ever has. It doesn't seem to go on sale very often though.

content:
Posted: January 2, 2015
												Pros: Both combat and puzzles are challenging yet maintain a fresh feel throughout the game. Free roam. The game truly doesn't hold your hand. Hints are plentiful and usually both easy to find and understand. Level editor and custom dungeon support. Game length is around 20 hours on a first playthrough depending on how hard you search for secrets. Plenty of secrets and treasures for you to find and toy with. Many different possible playstyles and party composition. Several bonus difficulty modifiers. Also, normal doesn't feel like easy.Cons: 1v1 combat can be extremely easy once you learn the controls and monster ai. A flying enemy appears that is invulnerable to most types of damage far before most players have the ability to deal with it. Ran into a progress halting bug where a key didn't spawn. Upon reload, the key spawned. This could be a serious issue if a player is using some of the difficulty modifiers. Game design promotes certain party compositions and leaves some playstyles almost worthless. With the amount of available skills, it is disheartening seeing that you can only utilize a few per character due to the low amount of skill points received throughout. Specializing is key to effective party members from the start and there is no way to understand this without playing for several hours. If you are experienced or plan ahead, late game bosses and enemies become a bit easy as damage scaling coupled with potion usage makes for insanely strong builds.Overall, I found this game phenomenal. It steadily increases the challenge both through new variety in monsters and puzzles throughout a lengthy game in a natural way. The music is astounding and boss fights are intense. There are very few cheap traps and most puzzles can be solved quickly if you find and comprehend the hints provided. Secret doors are usually (almost always) audible from the location of the object that opens them so if you pay attention you can find them. If you get stuck, you can go to a different area for most of the game and come back later thanks to the free roam design. Enemies respawn (and get more difficult as your level increases) but it takes a considerable amount of time to the point where I've never seen them respawn in the current dungeon (note that I rarely slept throughout the game though). Progression is consistent and if you get stumped, walkthroughs will make you facepalm because the solution is usually right in front of your face. If you are looking for a challenging, enjoyable, long (compared to modern games), cheap (again compared to modern games), and gratifying game, Legend of Grimrock 2 could be the game for you.

They provide a good space to battle in and at the same time restrain you. The new leverage and water tiles are really cool and added a vast amount of new possibilities with map design. The new classes and the rat and lizard people where great additions.The puzzles are as expected well made with a few exceptions here and there but that is to be expected of a puzzle game. And the secrets are a blast to discover. and the addition of pirate treasures and chests where neat!this game is a must for anyone who wants more of the first Grimrock or want a puzzle game with intense moments and an emersive world this game is for you. It took me around 42 hours to complete this game so if you are short on time this game is maybe not the best buy thou. There is also a level editor for the workshop, sadly i find the workshop to be slightly lacking.

content:
Posted: October 18, 2014
												The Island of Nex, a worthy successor to the dank Grimrock mountain....In all fairness, Legend of Grimrock 2 takes the old formula from the original and evolves it in all the right ways. The main difference in the game is that instead of the sequential level design of the first game, LGR 2 has a more horizontal layout that allows more organic exploration then simple sequential levels. This does not confine the secrets (the many, many mind bending secrets) to simply the designated "dungeon" sections of the island either, in addition to simple little caches and puzzles on the island surface, you can find riddles and clues that can lead you to buried treasure chests, which was a great touch and encouraged backtracking (which was not much of a pain, the island has a small hub that links the major wings together). One flaw would be the diving mechanic, some tiles are covered in water and your party cannot stay in them for long without drowning, coupled with the fact there can be underwater enemies and your attack is disabled when underwater, you can get pinned into a corner and be unable to get out, resulting in you needing to load a previous save.The combat has been polished greatly from the first, rather then gaining perks that would allow for a random chance of a special attack, the weapons themselves have special attacks noted in their discription that can be activated by holding the attack button (at the cost of some energy/mana). All the spells from LGR 1 make their return, as well as some more interesting ones, but I do believe that more spells should have been implimented. However, the requirments to cast the spells have been reduced as a result of a simpler leveling system, so your mage is no longer a "one trick pony".The leveling system was revamped from the original, all skills now only have 5 levels instead of 50, and you gain one point to spend per level. One thing of note is that your stats now level automatically (but can be enhanced by drinking special potions) depending on your class, which can be a bad thing if you really want full control over your characters' growth, but not everyone does so its more of a neutral point. The skills also have milestone perks and per level upgrades, similar to the original. Overall the leveling system was streamlined rather then completely changed.One mechanic that was greatly expanded was the alchemy system, which acts as the party's healing. There are more ingredients, more potions and the potion interface is similar to the spell casting interface so it can be used in combat with ease (something the first game needed badly). Your alchemist can also make bombs which act as one time spells with additional effects (freezing the enemy, setting the ground alight, etc). The greatest alchemist can even cheat death, if you find the correct recipe that is.Overall, there are more items, more enemies, more ground to cover, more dungeons to dive into and more secrets to uncover. I would give the game a 9/10, it would be a perfect 10 if not for the annoying water sections and the lack of very many new spells. A great game, if you liked the first one, get this one, if you never played the first one, consider getting this one, the stories are independent and the second one is a bit stronger gameplay wise.

												Magnificent. They kept everything that was great in Legend of Grimrock 1 and expanded on it. It feels even bigger than the original and I can't put it down. As a racing simulator lover might not love an FPS, and this game is a sub genre all on its own. The closest comparison I would make would be to an RPG (though I personaly enjoy LoGR's combat system more than any RPG's I've played) with more puzzles, but it really is D&D the video game.

content:
Posted: June 16, 2015
												[Warning: Long Review]Seeing as Grimrock 1 is my favourite dungeon crawler, I got very excited when this sequel was announced. Unfortunately, my graphics card was kinda broken, so the game kept crashing when I attempted to play it. Booo. Now though, I have finally found a graphics card and the time needed to play it. So I booted the game, put the game on old-school hard difficulty, brought out my notebook with chequered paper and crashed my ship.With that said, a party of adventurers washed up upon the Isle of Nex. They were:In the top left: "Goat C", the minotaur barbarian. She smashes things with the heaviest weapons available and is being kept alive by carrying the heaviest armour available. Does a lot of damage to everything, but is slow and prone to missing enemies right in front of her.In the bottom left: "Harry", the insectoid wizard. She casts spells that, if elemental weaknesses apply, wreck enemies dead in no time - until she runs out of mana. Unfortunately, Harry decided to put one point in each magic school to test all low-level spells, so she can't use the more powerful ones until later, which requires a LOT of skill points. If she could start over again, she would wait with assigning skill points until said powerful spells were found.In the bottom right: "Elizabeth", the lizardman alchemist. Holy♥♥♥♥♥♥ alchemist is so stronk! The whole party would have died many times over if not for Elizabeth. Apparently her backpack is magical, because inside of it potion ingredients multiply! Holy♥♥♥♥♥♥that is so broken. So, Lizzy keeps the party alive and fuels Harry's destructive powers. Also she slings rocks and darts at the enemies basically dealing zero damage....and in the top right I have inserted myself into my fantasy journey: "Brunkuhrskrunkuhr II", son of "Brunkuhrshkrunkuhr   I", one of the survivours of Grimrock I. I am a ratling farmer. When I read the description for the farmer class (no xp from kills, only xp from picking locks and eating food, starts with no skills) I thought; "damn! This is the definition of a joke class! And since it's a joke class, it'll probably be insanely powerful late-game!" One thing I remembered from Grimrock 1 was that I never ever was in any shortage for food, ever, so I would probably reach level cap in no time!  And it seemed I was right; "Brunkuhrskrunkuhr II" soon leveled far beyond his companions, mastering light weapons and light armours. But then something happened while I was deep inside a dark, damp dungeon with dastardly demons delivering deadly deliveries... I ran out of food.Grimrock II is substantially more difficult than the first game. Enemies are faster, have more health, deal more damage and above all else are smarter = exploiting the square grids on which the game is based is harder. So one has to think more strategically, observe enemy patterns and weaknesses, then deliver the hurt. To exemplify: there is an insanely fast mosqito swarm you can't outrun that deals unholy amounts of damage, but it dies in one hit to the first fire spell you find. There's sentient rocks that take pathetic amounts of damage from physical attacks...unless you get a critical hit. Overall, the enemies are well-designed and challenging.Grimrock II lacks one thing from it's predecessor - cohesivness. Where in Grimrock 1 you finish everything on one floor, then move to the next, solve the puzzles there, slay the giant trolls, then move to the next floor, etc. while always being in the same, huge dungeon, here the maps are more of a patchwork of different enviroments, with some puzzles extending over several maps and the maps having several exits in all three dimensions. So while in the first game you always knew where you were heading, this game requires a lot more exploration. It's kind of like a Metroidvania game. I want to get to the big castle. To do that I require 4 keys. One is on Sleet Island. How do I get onto sleet Island? I get a hint that the answer is in the cemetery. How do I get into the cemetary? I get a hint that the answer is in the archives. How do I get in the archives? I need to cast a long-range spell to extend a bridge that isn't ice spikes, like fireball! Where do I find fireball? In the dungeon you get to by extending said bridge! FUUUUU- So while I like Grimrock II for trying a different approach, I feel that much of the wholeness of the original game goes lost. And the farmer class would be much more OP if I knew where I was going and didn't waste food by walking everywhere.While Grimrock 1 had deliberately extremely minimal graphics, with every wall looking the same, Grimrock 2 is substantially more diverse and at times beautiful. So +1 to graphics. However, it does lead to ridiculous circumstances as where I cannot cross a small patch of grass because in gameplay it's the same as a solid rock wall.The puzzles are still decent, basically more of the same. Some are bad, like the aforementioned bridge-extnding that requires you to put points into skills you don't want. Some are dull, like looking for hidden buttons on the identical walls. Some are decent, like trying to time dropping a giant spider so it stays trapped at the right spot and doesn't come out to kill you. Some are good, like attempting to decipher treasure maps and codes. ...and some are traps. Allow me to quote my notes: "This is a trap if I've ever seen one." "Itsatrap! Jumpscurz" and one that made me smirk: An alcove in the wall containing a powerful magical book placed over a closed trapdoor with a sign next to it reading: "I dare you."I'm writing this review inside a dark dungeon where I have repeatedly died trying to kill the same enemies in order to get the coode to the archives, where my provisions have run dry (because I ate all the food) and Harry is starving. I'm torn between continuing to push forward or to shamefully backtrack to the surface to catch some fish. As we sit in the flickering light of our single, failing torch and not even Goats stoic expression can hide her despair, when our legs be broken from jumping into pits, when my hand-dawn maps are incomplete and we hear the monsters endlessly crawling around us I gush and exclaim: "I Love Grimrock!"Then we're off to die again.-Edit: I have now finished the game, finally. Both endings. It took a long time, since I tried to find most secrets (but failed, ♥♥♥♥ing pixel hunts) and, you know, drew my own maps. I just have to say it's a shame games this good aren't being made as often. The feeling of adventure, the atmosphere of exploration, the intense battles... 10/10 would recommend, "like dungeon crawling meets the Myst series."

												Magnificent. They kept everything that was great in Legend of Grimrock 1 and expanded on it. It feels even bigger than the original and I can't put it down. It has monsters, combat, exploration, puzzles out the wazoo, even an occational scare! I have on multiple occations shouted out loud when some brand new beast rounds a corner and I'm caught with my pants down.It creates a great sense of adventure.What LoGR2 does different than LoGR1:-a wider variety of areas (swamps, beaches, castles, forests, and [don't you worry] more dungeons! And they are BEAUTIFUL)-non-linear exploration. (or at least more than before. think, 6 paths you need to complete but you chose the order and can backtrack)-vertical multi-level elements-a simpler, faster potion crafting system-more class types-a fifth species of characterWhat 2 still has from 1:-loads of monsters (most of them new [and more variety than even before], but you see some familiar faces)-loads of loot-loads of satisfying puzzles!If you liked the first, you'll love the second. I rather don't have a single negative thing to say about the game, but I will warn that it won't be for everyone. As a racing simulator lover might not love an FPS, and this game is a sub genre all on its own. The closest comparison I would make would be to an RPG (though I personaly enjoy LoGR's combat system more than any RPG's I've played) with more puzzles, but it really is D&D the video game.

content:
Posted: January 2, 2015
												Pros: Both combat and puzzles are challenging yet maintain a fresh feel throughout the game. Free roam. The game truly doesn't hold your hand. Hints are plentiful and usually both easy to find and understand. Level editor and custom dungeon support. Game length is around 20 hours on a first playthrough depending on how hard you search for secrets. Plenty of secrets and treasures for you to find and toy with. Many different possible playstyles and party composition. Several bonus difficulty modifiers. Also, normal doesn't feel like easy.Cons: 1v1 combat can be extremely easy once you learn the controls and monster ai. A flying enemy appears that is invulnerable to most types of damage far before most players have the ability to deal with it. Ran into a progress halting bug where a key didn't spawn. Upon reload, the key spawned. This could be a serious issue if a player is using some of the difficulty modifiers. Game design promotes certain party compositions and leaves some playstyles almost worthless. With the amount of available skills, it is disheartening seeing that you can only utilize a few per character due to the low amount of skill points received throughout. Specializing is key to effective party members from the start and there is no way to understand this without playing for several hours. If you are experienced or plan ahead, late game bosses and enemies become a bit easy as damage scaling coupled with potion usage makes for insanely strong builds.Overall, I found this game phenomenal. It steadily increases the challenge both through new variety in monsters and puzzles throughout a lengthy game in a natural way. The music is astounding and boss fights are intense. There are very few cheap traps and most puzzles can be solved quickly if you find and comprehend the hints provided. Secret doors are usually (almost always) audible from the location of the object that opens them so if you pay attention you can find them. If you get stuck, you can go to a different area for most of the game and come back later thanks to the free roam design. Enemies respawn (and get more difficult as your level increases) but it takes a considerable amount of time to the point where I've never seen them respawn in the current dungeon (note that I rarely slept throughout the game though). Progression is consistent and if you get stumped, walkthroughs will make you facepalm because the solution is usually right in front of your face. If you are looking for a challenging, enjoyable, long (compared to modern games), cheap (again compared to modern games), and gratifying game, Legend of Grimrock 2 could be the game for you.

content:
Posted: January 28, 2015
												Grimrock 2 takes a game that I already loved and adds greatness to it in nearly every aspect. Now the whole setting is a singular map (as opposed to seperate levels), and you can travel back to old areas via a "hub" system. Also new are some very unique enemies, boss fights, outdoor settings, and creepy sequences where the island's antagonist pops up unexpectedly. In addition, there are now firearms, which prove to be an interesting skill to level. You can expect a foreboding and mysterious setting with many puzzles that require you to think outside the box at times. Enemies will cause you to jump in your seat when they pop up behind you, or quickly enter a room once you've solved a puzzle. They are legitimately difficult and you will have to choose your fights carefully until you get some of the better weapons in the game. If you're new to the game, or get frustrated easily, I'd recommend doing your first play through in easy mode, it prevents the enemies from being too overwhelming and allows you to concentrate on puzzles and exploration. You may be temped to run to the internet for help on the puzzles, however you should know that the greatest fulfillment, which goes hand-in-hand with the enjoyment of the game, comes from solving the puzzles yourself. Those "a-ha moments" are what makes Grimrock 2 stand out among its peers.Minor quibbles include a couple of puzzles which were overly cryptic, and if you are patient, being able to swivel around difficult enemies continually without taking damage due to the tile-based system. In Grimrock 3, I'd like to see enemies that can walk to the next tile and attack you from their side, that would definitely require additional strategy. Overall, easily one of my favorite games of all time, easily in my top 5, and I've been playing for quite some time. If you're on the fence, you need to try Grimrock, you won't be able to put it down!

content:
Posted: December 28, 2014
												A sequel that seems to improve from the original in every way. Pros:- Fantastic level design. Features an outside world that can lead to dungeons, and then dungeons that can connect to other dungeons. It makes the world feel interconnected and organic.- Clever puzzles. The majority of the puzzles in the game are very mind-bending while also being reasonable enough to solve on your own. - Improved Combat. The enemy AI isn't perfect, but it's pretty damn good. Enemys will often move try to pin you down, dodge, and even flee. Also, if you're a wizard-lover like me, you'll greatly appreciate the improvements to the spell system, and the skill tree system as a whole.- VARIETY. This game does a fantastic job of making the world varied enough to keep it fresh while also making it consistant enough to make the world feel connected. Just when you start getting sick of an enemy type or a weapon that you have. the game will throw in something new. Even the puzzles have a decent amount of variety to them with some being reflex-based, being observent of your surroundings, thinking outside the box, and even cracking codes!Cons (I'm gonna be honest, these are pretty nitpicky):- While the inclusion of guns is nice, I feel as though they were a bit of a missed opportunity. I came across maybe a total of 3 or 4 firearms on my 1st playthrough, and for the often pitiful damage they do they aren't worth it for the amount of times they seem to malfunction and backfire. There is a firearm that's good, but you'll hardly use it out of fear of wasting the very small amount of ammo it has. Hopefully, they'll be buffed for Grimrock 3. *crossing every finger I got*- 2 or 3 puzzles in the game felt a bit lazy or too ambiguous, but they're greatly overshadowed by the amount of good puzzles in the game.- Legend of Grimrock 3 hasn't been made yet.10/10, Even if you're not a fan of dungeon crawlers, after this game you will be, take it from me, a guy who's never played a dungeon crawler before this one.

												Legend of Grimrock 2 will surprise you no matter whether you're fresh off the back of LoG1, are experienced with this style of game from the past, or are completely new to it entirely.The game is a ridiculously huge improvement from the first -- with a rich open world with copious amounts of surprises and secrets that will have you scanning every wall for those precious buttons, cracking codes scrawled on notes by long-dead adventurers, or chasing pesky leprochaun-like tricksters across the world while grabbing armfuls of hidden goodies along the way. Heck, it may even throw the occasional jump-scare to keep you on your toes if you find yourself fully relaxed and enveloped, like I was. Nope, I wasn't expecting that thing to jump at me, or to be ambushed during a nap.Make your adventure-squad and set-sail for puzzling fun. When you need a break, take on an impressive beastiary with swords, shields and spells. A lot of the old cast have returned - as have new ones. Combat can still be cheesed like before at times, though the game will throw trump cards at you if you rely too heavily on it - and there's some pretty nasty boss-battles in store to boot.Three out of two thumbs up for this relaxing-to-frustrating rollercoaster that'll have you fist-pumping on the completion of every puzzle or after emerging victorious from hard-fought battles.Loving it!

												A very very good sequel worthy of its name. Legend of Grimrock 2 features many of the familiar mechanics seen in the first game, yet it improves upon the AI significantly, where they are less rigid in movement and are able to avoid your strikes or even counter-attack you as you move to their side, seemingly learning from your actions (a tactic commonly used in the first, where you strafe to their side and attack before strafing away). It features the grid-based movement and introduces new weapons, weapon attacks (special attacks) and a new race to boot. The puzzles are more interesting this time around and arguably the difficulty has been upped. Boss battles are exciting and there are many hidden areas for you to find, with each hidden area becoming more and more difficult to discover as its clues become more subtle. The maps have also been increased in size, where multiple paths can be taken for you to try out different puzzles, leaving you with the option to come back later if you wish. The visuals have also been improved and are quite impressive. A definite must-buy if you are a fan of the first game.

Posted: February 3, 2016
												The Legend of Grimrock 2 is a throwback to the time of Ultima: Underworld, but with better graphics and deliciously enjoyable puzzles and secrets.The 40+ hours I spent on this game were enjoyable, nostalgic, and satisfying in equal parts. The puzzles are not designed to be extremely difficult, PROVIDED you find the proper clues for them. Backtracking is a necessity in this game, which focuses in a more messhed approach where the entire map offers secrets in the early, middle, and late game.  In fact, there are TWO endings, which I found very interesting.Though the game allows for a playthrough with any character class, I observed that a mage/wizard/spellcaster of some kind makes the game a lot more playable and, more importantly ---> you MUST have someone with the ability to cast spells (or at least invested 1 point into Concentration, the main spell casting requirement and have a low requirement wand) if you want to find the 2nd ending.That I didn't enjoy, the fact that if I had chosen all non-casters that I wouldn't have been able to get to the 2nd end.Also, the last 3 boss fights are monumentally more survivable with long range attacks. These are not reasons to avoid the title. It is such a rewarding experience for the genre. If you love puzzles, secrets, and old school dungeon crawling remniscent of table-top maps, this is the game for you.Buy it. Play it. It is a darn satisfying game.

content:
Posted: July 11, 2016
												In short: Fun, beautiful and a bit difficult old school challenge. Like it's predecessor it's a tip of the hat to the classic grid based fantasy roleplaying games back in the 90's, like Eye of the Beholder. It's a good mix of tough monsters and tricky puzzles, and there's a lot of variety in level design and theme for the different areas. Legend of Grimrock 2 adds outdoor areas, height differences (and ladders), underwater areas amongst other things, as well as new character options and both new and old familiar monsters. Some areas have quite impressive visuals that made me stop and savour it. And on top of it, it has multiple endings too. Well done, devs.A few puzzles were pretty much impossible for me to solve (or rather, realise what they wanted me to do), despite being attentive to a lot of details and finding most secrets without help. Thankfully there are a lot of online resources if you get stuck (always try a lot first yourself) but at the end of it, the puzzle part is good but there's room for improvement.Combat is mean, in the sense that you can't straight up fight anything. If you do, you're dead. Square circling or sidestepping is a must for surviving any encounter. This is just how LoG works but I think I would prefer a more straight on approach. On the good side, a lot of monsters have abilities that work against the circling, so it's still a fun challenge. The monsters are varied and fresh but if I should be building new maps with the ingame level editor I would like some of the more classical fantasy monsters as well.If you liked LoG1 or other games of the genre, it's definitely worth a buy.

content:
Posted: January 2, 2016
												A worthy successor to the board-like dungeon crawler known as Grimrock I. Both of them seem to hit that sweet spot between making a game look good and leaving things to your imagination. It's tough to describe, but there's just this feeling of charm to it few games have nowadays. Combining old-school gameplay with graphics on par with the Trine series does work out for this one.While the core mechanics remain the same, pretty much every aspect of the game has been expanded upon. No longer are you limited to dungeons, you actually get to explore some outside environments for once. They look daaaamn good too, especially the beach. The new campaign only starts out linear to ease you into things, but after the first two areas you end up in a hub-world from where you choose to go next. There are new puzzles that aren't limited to "put rock on pressure plate", new items, more monsters, more classes, etc. Speaking of items, weapons have special moves now. Also day-and-night cycle.However, I don't think this game would be the same without the editor, which alone is enough to make cool maps. It doesn't take much at all to create your own levels, the editor's fairly simple to use for a 3d game. To make it even better, you can use lua scripts and custom assets to make your dungeon even more interesting. You could create some intricate puzzles, boss fights, or even add your own tiles, objects, and enemies if you have a bit of know-how.What else can I say, I highly recommend LoG2. It's a very solid upgrade from the first game, and even though I'm not even a quarter through, this game satiates my thirst for a chill video game sesh better than Skyrim ever has. It doesn't seem to go on sale very often though.

Posted: August 11, 2016
												A triumphant sequel! Looks great, sounds great and plays identical to the first but with more potential build diversity. Some of the secrets and riddles are rather devilish in nature so expect to have your mental capacity stretched as you try to work your way around some of the more obscure puzzles...or just consult a guide for some extra clues/the complete solution. Like the first game, I enjoyed the story for what it facilitated but it generally feels rather redundant in the context of what one would like from such a game.My only real negative is the skills system - I really think there needed to be more traits in each skill line. There should always be an interesting bonus at the end of each skill line to entice the player to spend more points into single lines at the expense of skill diversity. I generally found there was no difficult choices to make with skill point allocation because you rarely had to max out a skill line to achieve its most important trait. Other than that, it's a perfect sequel.

 DISCLAIMER: This is a first impressions review, and NOT a full review, if you want a full review, then please read better reviews then mine After you manage to find your way out and escape Mount Grimrock, you become shipwrecked on an island and your only objective is to find a way out and survive, will you manage?Legend of Grimrock 2 is a game developed and published by Almost Human Games and is the sequel to the first dungeon crawler game; Legend of Grimrock. Legend of Grimrock 2 puts you in control of a group of four prisoners aiming to find their way out off an island. Search for secrets, find clothes, weapons and armours and continuously upgrade the abilities of your party membersIt is a wonderful game if you are willing to immerse into it. But it requires a lot of patience and endurance because it's a very difficult game. The game allows you to set up your personal party, choosing the race and abilities of your members or you can simply start by using a pre-defined group. As an old-fashioned dungeon crawler you can only move one step at a time in one directionLegend of Grimrock 2 has great atmosphere with nice and improved graphics from the first game and addictive game with extremely good and varied puzzle design with many different and gradually stronger enemies and mysterious hints that gradually reveal the story and are very rewardingThe mazes can be maddening at times but at the same time this adds to the claustrophobic mood the game is trying to portray, however, Legend of Grimrock 2 isn't easy so be prepared to die a lotOverall, Legend of Grimrock 2 is a fun dungeon crawler to play in bursts and is a great return to the Legend of Grimrock series! RECOMMENDED :)

												Fun game.  Reminds me of Eye of the Beholder series with better graphics.  Some of the puzzles are a bit too convoluted to be solved using just what's given in the game.  One puzzle requires you to convert numbers into binary.  I was completely stumped and learned that from a game guide.  I'm all for tricky puzzles, but then you need to have some reasonable hints. 												What an excellent retro RPG.As a person who played the original Dungeon Master, All the Eye of the Beholder Series and many others on the Amiga back in the day this game brings back great memories.  Indeed someone developed the Dungeon Master dungeon for this game as a DLC and it was great to play. I was amazed at how much I remembered from 25 years ago!Its a turn based game on a tiled map, in the same way as the original.  That is not to its detriment though.  It beats the crap out of many new full 3D shoot-em-ups in sheer gameplay - the complexity of the puzzles and mazes and the progressively more difficult monsters which will catch you out if you don't upgrade your characters to match.   I played the original dungeon and then several more player dungeons before I hd hard enough.  If you like this Genre then this is one of the best examples ever created.

Posted: January 8
												What an excellent retro RPG.As a person who played the original Dungeon Master, All the Eye of the Beholder Series and many others on the Amiga back in the day this game brings back great memories.  Indeed someone developed the Dungeon Master dungeon for this game as a DLC and it was great to play. I was amazed at how much I remembered from 25 years ago!Its a turn based game on a tiled map, in the same way as the original.  That is not to its detriment though.  It beats the crap out of many new full 3D shoot-em-ups in sheer gameplay - the complexity of the puzzles and mazes and the progressively more difficult monsters which will catch you out if you don't upgrade your characters to match.   I played the original dungeon and then several more player dungeons before I hd hard enough.  If you like this Genre then this is one of the best examples ever created.

												Fun game.  Reminds me of Eye of the Beholder series with better graphics.  Some of the puzzles are a bit too convoluted to be solved using just what's given in the game.  One puzzle requires you to convert numbers into binary.  I was completely stumped and learned that from a game guide.  I'm all for tricky puzzles, but then you need to have some reasonable hints.  The character classes, races, and leveling system are simple, but good.  Down side is that you need to gain a bunch of levels to do some of the nifty things in the game.  Not sure I'll play it again.  It has options to play custom dungeons, so I'll probably search online for some of those.

content:
Posted: January 18
												Amazing grid-style dungeon crawler/western style RPG. I love pretty much everything about this game and the mysterious, dangerous, puzzled filled and monster infested island that my 4 shipwrecked escaped prisoners find themselves stranded on. Modern visuals/sound/execution, with a retro style, classic heart. Some people don't seem to care for the more "live action" combat style, and I was a little iffy on it, at first, myself. I warmed up to it though, and I don't think a more turn based fighting system would suit the game. It might make for a difficult time at first, if you have never played a game like this before, but its well made and very well balanced, once you get the hang of it.I absolutely recommend this game, with one suggestion: look up some character builds before setting out, even if you ultimately decide to branch out and do something completely different. Understanding the strengths of each class, what perks and traits benefit the playstyle you have in mind, and knowing what to do with your points as you level is paramount to having a good time on this island. I won't say its impossible to build a hybrid character but you typically won't have any points to spare or waste, and you also probably won't have nearly as many of them (or levels) as you envision - and spreading yourself too thin is a huge mistake in this place.

content:
Posted: January 10
												Legend of Grimrock 2 is similar to the first game in a lot of ways but this game is set outdoors on the Island of Nex which allowed for bigger areas. The skill system has been overhauled and way less linear as you can increase any type of skill regardless of your class, classes only provide some bonuses and such but you can progress whatever you want. They also retained the unique rune based magic grid casting system but instead of clicking on each rune you have to connect a line between runes to cast spells. Another thing this sequel retains is the amazing atmosphere and story through notes you find throughout the game. Their are 5 races which are humans, insectoids, minotaurs, lizardmen, and ratlings. you can create 4 characters for your party like the first game and they also added firearms to the game as a new weapon type and skill as well as overhauling the alchemy system by adding an alchemy skill and a plethora of ingredients and potions which are very useful as well as elemental bombs. I hope my review has convinced you to buy this amazing game but I recommend you play the first one as it is easier to learn and get players into the genre of party based dungeon crawlers of the olden days. Hopefully the Legend of Grimrock series gets more players into this type of RPG because their are a handful of these kinds of games from the 90s that are amazing such as the Might and Magic franchise or Eye of the Beholder series and much more. Thank you if you read this review and please buy Legend of Grimrock 2 as it is a sequel done right in every single way but Legend of Grimrock 1 is an amazing game as well and much better at getting players into these games.

												oh boy oh boy, as my Legend of Grimrock review made it abundantly clearhttp://steamcommunity.com/id/nuclearkangaroo/recommended/207170/LoG1 is one of my favorite indie games, and Legend of Grimrock 2 is one of my favorite games EVER period.the best way to describe this game is "Legend of Grimrock... but BETTER", more Legendary, more Grim, more Rocky, all the base mechanics from the 1st game remain in place so i wont waste much time explaining itthe Legend of Grimrock series is a grind based dungeon crawler RPG series in which you control a group of 4 characters, you fight monsters and solve puzzles, thats the short verion. what makes LoG2 even superior to its predessesor is content, variety and the expansion of the core mechanics, instead of exploring a single big dungeon in the game, you explore an island filled with multiple dungeons and secrets, to returning players of the series this game truthly changes things up with the addition of these open environments and the classic dungeon gameplay is still there, you only have to enter the numerous caves, temples and dungeons to experience it againthe basic combat has also been expanded, the game now has a new type of weapon, guns as well as 5 new character classes and a new race, the ratling, also the devs have made other classes besides the mage a little more fun to use (the mage remains just as fun to use dont worry), certain weapons now have special attacks that add versatility to each character and you unlock new perks and abilities as you level up your class skillspuzzles, a major feature of the last game are back and with force, this game has some very incredible puzzles, almost all of them are hard but fair, i can really count 1 or 2 puzzles AT MOST in the entire game that followed a very weird logic, for almost everything else, you just need to use yer brains, im actually very proud of the fact i didnt need to use a guide for any of the puzzles in this game, unlike the first gameenemies also received an overhaul, the main strategy of the first game, running in circles around them, is much less effective now since the enemies turn faster and many have moves that make it very hard for the player to circle strafe, and hell the game now has more than 1 boss and they are all great and challengingif theres one thing i wasnt a fan of in this game, is the new limb injury system, basically, some enemies/traps/enemy attacks have a chance of crippling your head/legs/feet/right arm/left arm, each crippled limb applies a different debuff, these can only be removed by either consuming a red potion or touching a save crystal, now this on itself is not bad, except for the fact that FALLING DOWN PITS CAN CRIPPLE YOUR LEGS AND/OR FEET, those who played the first game should be able to see the problem with this, the LoG series often hides secrets or alternate routes down pits, there are no "bottomless pits" in these games, every pit leads to a lower level you can explore, usually you will want to use the stairs tough, because in the first game, falling down these pits hurt you, in LoG2 however, it hurts you and CAN cripple you, this is made worse by the fact some puzzle and obstacles send you down pits if you fail them, adding to the frustration. now to be fair Lo♥♥♥♥dded a new item, the rope, which allows you to descent pits without taking any damage, still, until you manage to find a rope, your LoG1 habits might lead you to a nasty experiencei suggest anybody interested in LoG2 plays LoG1 first for two reasons:1) its a great introduction to LoG2, since the game doesnt have a particularly good tutorial, those who played LoG1 should be able to get around LoG2's mechanics more easily2) this game is such an upgrade over the first game that is almost impossible to go back once you finish LoG2, is just so much better than a game that was already greati cannot recommend Legend of Grimrock 2 enough, its my 9th favorite game of all time, a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ masterpiece
